Munden, who has learning difficulties and was detained under the Mental Health Act following a 2021 conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy build, and having dark hair. He may have shaved off his beard before disappearing. Munden, formerly from Marchwood near Southampton, was initially arrested after attempting to download child abuse images at Hythe library. The court heard he had a collection of children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home, indicating a fanatical interest in young girls. Despite his denial of deliberate intent, Munden was deemed a significant risk due to the escalation from non-contact to contact offenses. Police are urgently seeking information about his whereabouts, emphasizing the need to locate him due to his hospital order and learning difficulties.

V. Stiviano, a female companion of Donald Sterling, the former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts given to her by Sterling. This decision came after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, Donald's wife, sued Stiviano, alleging that Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and that Donald used the couple's funds to buy her luxury vehicles and a high-end duplex. Stiviano contended that there was no wrongdoing in Sterling's gifts, asserting she never took advantage of him. Shelly Sterling expressed satisfaction with the court's ruling, emphasizing it as a victory for the family in recovering the gifts and setting a precedent for spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill-gotten gifts. The gifts included extravagant items like a Ferrari, Bentleys, a Range Rover, an Easter bunny costume, a blender, and a lace thong. Donald Sterling's downfall was triggered by an audio recording where he made racist remarks to Stiviano, leading to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights in the Clippers franchise.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and Sky Sports pundit, has criticized the club's transfer strategy, advocating for the signing of four key players in the summer to enhance their chances of winning the Premier League title. Henry identifies the need for a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-tier striker. He specifically targets Olivier Giroud, stating that Arsenal may struggle to secure the league title with him as their primary striker. Henry draws parallels to Chelsea's successful acquisition of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa, which he believes propelled them to league victory. Despite Giroud's impressive 14 league goals this season, Henry doubts Arsenal's ability to win the title with him as the focal point. Arsenal, currently third in the league, are level on points with Manchester City but hold a game in hand.

A young woman, who was a victim of sexual abuse by Bega Cheese CEO Maurice Van Ryn for years, testified in Sydney's District Court about the profound impact the abuse has had on her life. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, revealed she kept the abuse a secret for years, only breaking her silence after learning Van Ryn had been apprehended. She expressed fear about future relationships, stating that Van Ryn has "stolen her right to share her body with someone for the first time." The young woman, who was a child when the abuse occurred, didn't understand it was wrong and believed it was a common occurrence among friends. She has since struggled with depression since age 14, including hospitalizations for self-harm and suicide attempts. She is now scared of people discovering her past and worries about how the abuse will affect her future relationships with men. Van Ryn, currently in custody, is facing a hearing, and the victim is concerned about his potential release and its potential consequences.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is making a comeback after more than a year due to a severe knee injury sustained in March 2014. He last played for the first team in the Champions League against Bayern Munich. Gnabry, who previously impressed for Arsenal last season, has been recovering through matches with the Under-21 team. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's development squad in a 1-0 loss to Reading, indicating his progress. Gnabry expressed his satisfaction, stating he feels "better and better" and is eager to return to first-team action.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old graduate accountant from Reading, Berks, died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, in December. He and his friends, Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson, had caught a taxi home from a night out in Cardiff, but lacked sufficient cash for the fare. To avoid paying, Phillips ran from the taxi, which pursued him. In the dark, he leapt over a fence and plunged down a cliff at the end of a disused promenade. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, testified that he couldn't see where he was going and wasn't aware of the danger Phillips was in. Phillips' body was discovered the next day by a dog walker on the rocky beach. The coroner, Andrew Barkley, recorded an accidental death verdict, noting that Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the cliff's danger. Phillips, who worked for Liam Gallagher's clothing label, Pretty Green, had returned to Wales for Christmas and was staying with his mother in Cowbridge. He had planned to stay at a friend's house but couldn't afford the fare, leading to the fatal incident.

During the passport delay crisis in the summer of the previous year, thousands of holidaymakers who faced additional costs for rush-processing their passports did not receive any compensation from the HM Passport Office. Despite the agency's £42 million profit during this period, managers received substantial bonuses, with some receiving up to £3,500. The Home Affairs Committee, led by Keith Vaz, advocated for compensation but was disappointed to find only 2,191 applications approved out of 2,077 the previous year, totaling £203,066. The average compensation was £92.68, with the highest payout being £5,463 and the lowest £1. The Passport Office couldn't disclose the number of rejected claims due to a system failure in their customer complaint database. Ministers declined to offer blanket compensation to all affected individuals, citing the potential creation of a precedent. This left numerous holidaymakers, including Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham who lost nearly £1,500 on a trip to Morocco due to delayed passports, without any financial relief.

A 1930s-era, unaltered home in Horfield, Bristol, is being auctioned off with a guide price ranging from £200,000 to £250,000. This semi-detached property, which has remained untouched for over 80 years, showcases original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro food jars. The interior retains its vintage charm with the original bathroom and kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. The bathroom, in particular, stands out with its mint green and black tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper, and green sink. The house also includes a brick open-face fire, dated kitchen sink, and a high shelf in the hallway filled with original 1930s food items. Despite some modern upgrades like double glazing, the extensive renovation required to restore the property could deter developers. The auction is scheduled for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick, initially a backup to Alex Smith, took over as the 49ers' starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season due to Smith's concussion. He maintained this role throughout the season, guiding the team to their first Super Bowl appearance in 17 years since 1994. However, they lost the game to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food, a 1997 American comedy-drama film, was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds and his wife Tracey Edmonds, along with Robert Teitel. It was distributed by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, later relocated to Texas and San Francisco. Route 495, a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connects the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at Secaucus exits 16E and 17 to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) within the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken. This route offers access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is a Spanish-language television network in the United States, owned by Comcast's NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, born and raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon, forming the alternative rock band Blur. Their debut album, 'Leisure', was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. In 2001, Blur achieved worldwide success with their self-titled album. Albarn's solo career began with 'Everyday Robots' (2014), co-produced by Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir. The album also sampled rants by Lord Buckley, showcasing a diverse musical influence spanning alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most inhabited city of Somalia. It serves as the headquarters for numerous significant national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock group Nine Inch Nails, originally released as part of their debut extended play (EP), Broken, in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has received a BAFTA nomination for his work.

The 2007 film "Shooter" centers around Mark Wahlberg's character, Bob Lee Swagger, a seasoned Force Recon veteran. He is wrongly accused of murder by a rogue private military unit. In contrast, the TV series "Shooter" (2016-2018) features Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, a skilled marksman living in seclusion. The narrative picks up when Swagger is drawn back into action due to his knowledge of a plot to assassinate the U.S. President.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama that aired on Fox network for eight seasons, commencing from November 16, 2004, and concluding on May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 for orchestrating the murders of seven individuals, including actress Sharon Tate, and two others, Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. The murders were committed by members of his cult, following his instructions. Manson's songs, previously unreleased, were commercially released post-conviction.

Sean Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. His acting career commenced with a minor role in Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. Penn transitioned to film with Taps (1981) and gained recognition for his roles in Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). He garnered critical acclaim for his performance in Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received further nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, known as "The Don," was an exceptional Australian cricketer, celebrated for his unparalleled batting skills. After retiring, he maintained his significant influence in the sport through roles as an administrator, selector, and writer for over three decades.

L.A. Reid has held significant executive roles in several major music labels. He served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment, demonstrating his influence in the broader music industry. Additionally, he was the president and CEO of Arista Records, further solidifying his leadership in the industry. Lastly, he was the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group, showcasing his extensive experience in managing and overseeing multiple music divisions.

Brad Wilk, renowned as the drummer, has been a key member of two influential rock bands: Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career as a drummer for Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. Currently, he is part of the supergroup Prophets of Rage, alongside members from Rage, Audioslave, Public Enemy, Cypress Hill, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, initially a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner, is notable for its politically charged lyrics and innovative music style.

The Millers was a multi-camera sitcom that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes across two seasons. The series concluded on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season, following CBS's decision to cancel it.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, representing the Democratic party. She gained prominence as the state treasurer of Texas, delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas, known for her outspoken feminism and humorous one-liners. She was defeated in her bid for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards (1935-1982), on the other hand, was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell, in 2011, independently released an EP titled 'A Reminder'.

Boardwalk, a 1979 American drama film, was directed by Stephen Verona and written by Verona and Leigh Chapman. The film features Janet Leigh, an accomplished American actress, singer, dancer, and author. Born as Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, Leigh passed away on October 3, 2004. Throughout her career, she authored four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political figure who significantly contributed to the independence of several South American nations from Spanish rule. His influence extended to Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama, making him a pivotal figure in the region's liberation movement.

The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a geographically defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean. It's renowned for the disappearance of numerous aircraft and ships, with these incidents often attributed to mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick, initially a backup to Alex Smith, took over as the 49ers' starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season due to Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance in 18 years, but lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they were defeated by the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller movie directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a marketing strategy that uses nonpersonal, sponsored messages to promote products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, it doesn't target specific individuals. Advertising is disseminated via diverse media platforms, encompassing traditional ones like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and outdoor advertising, as well as modern ones such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.

Private Lives is a 1930 comedy play written by Noël Coward, which was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code film directed by Sidney Franklin. The play is a three-act comedy of manners, focusing on the chaotic reunion of two divorced individuals, Elyot and Amanda, who unexpectedly meet again at a seaside resort.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, born on 10 February 1894, was a prominent British Conservative politician and statesman. He held the position of Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 until 19 October 1963. He was also the 1st Earl of Stockton. Macmillan passed away on 29 December 1986.

Aristotle, born in Stagira, Chalkidice (384 BC), was a renowned Greek philosopher and scientist. He studied under Plato at the Academy in Athens from his teens until he was thirty-seven (c. 347 BC). Following Plato's death, Aristotle moved to Macedon at the invitation of King Philip II, where he served as a tutor to Alexander the Great, commencing in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American who has made significant contributions in the fields of arms dealing, music, invention, and entrepreneurship. He is renowned for inventing the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine. Currently, Packouz serves as the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Lakers from 1979 to 1991, won his first NBA championship and the Finals MVP award in his rookie season. He secured four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. Following protests from his teammates, he retired for four years before returning at 36 in 1996 for a brief 32-game stint. Johnson, recognized by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009, has diverse business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, California, established in 1994. The duo consists of Jack Black on lead vocals and guitar, and Kyle Gass on lead guitar and vocals. They have released three albums: 'Tenacious D' (2001), 'The Pick of Destiny' (2006), and 'Rize of the Fenix' (2012). Their initial recognition came in 1997 through their television series, 'Tenacious D', and their subsequent support of major rock bands.

James VI and I, born on 19 June 1566, reigned as King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. He ruled both Scotland and England in personal union, each maintaining their individual sovereignty with separate parliaments, judiciary, and laws. James was a proponent of a unified parliament for both nations. Despite his efforts in Scotland, he encountered significant challenges in England, notably the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and ongoing disputes with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming British reality TV series, set to air. It is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a renowned British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist. Bentley is particularly famous for narrating the UK's Big Brother since its launch in 2000, having transitioned from continuity announcer roles on Channel 4 to this position on Channel 5 in 2011. His distinctive Geordie accent and voice-over work have made him one of Britain's most recognizable voices.

Saxony, a landlocked federal state in Germany, shares borders with Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland (Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships), and the Czech Republic (Karlovy Vary, Liberec, and Ústí nad Labem Regions). It is the tenth largest state by area (18,413 km2) and the sixth most populous, with approximately 4 million inhabitants. Historically significant, Saxony has a millennium-long past, situated in the heart of a formerly predominantly German-speaking region in Europe. Apart from its political and geographical context, Saxony is also renowned for its wine production, specifically in the Saxony and Saale-Unstrut wine regions, which are the northernmost in Europe and the only two German wine regions located in former East Germany.

East End Park was a significant baseball stadium situated in Cincinnati's East End district, serving as a major league baseball venue. Meanwhile, "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B, also known as Melanie Brown, initiated her solo music journey by releasing the single "I Want You Back" in collaboration with Missy Elliott, under the Virgin Records label.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest child of Billy Ray Cyrus, and she is the sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (Pawn), a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, features Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting parts. The movie, released on 1st July 1994, was a significant box office success, ranking second for the year's highest grossing Indian films. It received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Initially, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead, completing several scenes before her untimely death. Raveena Tandon then took over the role. The film is notable for its popular songs that dominated the charts in 1994.
"Hourglass" is a track from the British electronic duo Disclosure, while it's also the fourteenth studio album by renowned singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born on December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He gained prominence for co-writing the 1987 action film "Lethal Weapon," which became a significant hit. His directorial debut was with the 2005 film "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang."
A View to a Kill, released in 1985, is the fourteenth installment in the James Bond film series. This film marks the final appearance of Roger Moore as the iconic MI6 agent, James Bond.

Papua, the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, encompasses the majority of western New Guinea. Historically, it was known as Irian Jaya, previously referred to as West Irian or Irian Barat. This region previously included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus, the first Roman Emperor, is believed to have passed away due to natural causes. However, there were unverified claims suggesting his wife, Livia, might have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez, known as J.Lo, entered the music scene in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6", featuring the hit single "If You Had My Love". In 2001, she achieved a significant milestone by releasing her second album, "J.Lo", concurrently with her film "The Wedding Planner", becoming the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week. Following her second divorce, Lopez's relationship with Ben Affleck, which was highly publicized, heavily impacted her third album, "This Is Me... Then" (2002), and overshadowed the release of "Gigli" (2003), a critically and commercially unsuccessful film. After marrying Marc Anthony, Lopez experienced box office success with "Shall We Dance?" and gave birth to twins in 2008. She regained prominence in 2011, appearing as a judge on American Idol and releasing the commercially successful single "On the Floor", one of the best-selling singles of all time.

Working animals are domesticated creatures, often part of human families, trained to execute specific tasks. These tasks can range from assistance roles like guiding or herding, requiring human training to ensure cooperation, to providing tractive force, such as draft horses or elephants used in logging. Rarely, wild animals may be tamed and trained for work, typically for entertainment or novelty, as they generally lack the dependable and gentle nature inherent in true domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad (1998) is a direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter, featuring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. In contrast, Top Latin Albums and Regional Mexican Albums are two distinct record charts published by Billboard magazine. Top Latin Albums is the primary chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market. Regional Mexican Albums, on the other hand, is a weekly genre-specific chart for Mexican music in the U.S.

Vedam, a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film, was directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi and written by him as well. The movie features an ensemble cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II, released in 2002, is a science fiction action comedy film. The main cast includes Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a character from Don Quixote, a novel by Spanish author Cervantes, published in 1605. He serves as Don Quixote's squire and contributes to the narrative through his sanchismos, which are humorous, proverbial, and candid remarks. These remarks reflect Sancho's unique blend of wit, irony, and earthy humor.

The Adventures of Pluto Nash, a 2002 film, is a blend of science fiction, action, and comedy genres. It features Eddie Murphy in a dual role and is directed by Ron Underwood. The movie is of Australian-American origin.
Hedda Gabler, a play by Henrik Ibsen, had its world premiere on 31st January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company headquartered in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Roth, born on May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, commonly referred to as Juve, is a prominent Italian professional football club based in Turin, Piedmont. Established in 1897 by a group of young Torinese students, it is the second oldest active football club in Italy, following Genoa's football section (1893). The club's iconic black and white striped home kit was adopted in 1903. Over the years, Juventus has played its home matches in various stadiums, with the most recent one being the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis, a renowned actress, began her career in the late 1990s and early 2000s, appearing in supporting and minor roles across various films and television series. Notable film appearances include Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002). Additionally, she contributed to the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur and former pornographic film actress, renowned as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer, often referred to as "The Queen of Porn." She began her career in 1993, transitioning from a stripper and glamor model, by acting in erotic videos.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a team in the National Basketball Association (NBA), specifically part of the Western Conference's Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event, initially organized by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) from 1983 to 2000. The event was traditionally held on major holidays, primarily at Greensboro Coliseum, with JCP's Thanksgiving and Christmas events from the 1960s to the 1980s. Notable Starrcade events include:

- Starrcade 1985, the third annual event under the NWA banner.
- Starrcade 1987, the fifth annual event under the NWA banner.
- Starrcade 1997, the fifteenth annual event, transitioning to a pay-per-view (PPV) format.

Jack Ryan Falahee, born on February 20, 1989, is an American actor. He gained prominence for his character Connor Walsh in the ABC series 'How to Get Away with Murder', a legal drama. Additionally, he portrayed Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama 'Mercy Street'.

Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress born on June 28, 1991, under the stage name Seo Ju-hyun, made her solo debut with the extended play 'Don't Say No' on January 17, 2017. She is renowned for her role in the popular girl group Girls' Generation, which she joined in August 2007, and its subgroup TTS. Girls' Generation, under her leadership, achieved significant success in South Korea and globally, becoming one of the best-selling artists and most popular girl groups. Apart from her group's activities, Seohyun has ventured into acting, notably in stage musicals like 'Moon Embracing the Sun', 'Gone with the Wind', and 'Mamma Mia'. 'Don't Say No' marked her third solo debut, following her group members.

The Apple II, an 8-bit home computer, was a pioneering mass-produced microcomputer, primarily designed by Steve Wozniak. Its development was overseen by Steve Jobs, who also contributed to its case design and power supply. The Apple II series, trademarked as "Apple ] [ " and later as "Apple / / ", was introduced in 1977 by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Wozniak, born on August 11, 1950, is an American inventor, engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc. alongside Jobs.

A&E, previously known as Arts & Entertainment Network, is a prominent American cable and satellite television channel. It functions as the primary television property for A&E Networks, a 50-50 joint venture between Hearst Corporation and Disney's ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid is a prominent figure in the music industry, having held key leadership roles in several major record labels. He served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, a division of Sony Music Entertainment, and as the president and CEO of Arista Records. Additionally, he was the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group. Reid's entrepreneurial spirit is further demonstrated by his founding and CEO position at Hitco Music Publishing, and his co-founding of LaFace Records.

Veeram, a Tamil action film, was directed by Siva and released in 2014 under Vijaya Productions. In contrast, a different Veeram, an epic historical drama, was directed by Jayaraj and released in 2016. The 2016 Veeram is a standalone production, not a sequel to the 2014 version.

Home for the Holidays (1972) is a classic American made-for-television horror film, directed by John Llewellyn Moxey and produced by Aaron Spelling. It features a star-studded cast including Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. The original film premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. The 1995 remake, titled Home for the Holidays, boasts a different cast: Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born on April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
The Sex Factor is a reality TV series, created by xHamster, featuring eight male and eight female contestants. The objective of the show is for them to vie for the role of a porn star.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a dual-nationality musician, hailing from Lebanese and Armenian heritage. He is renowned as a songwriter and drummer in the music industry.
Island Records is a record label, functioning as a division of Universal Music Group (UMG), and it is based in both the United Kingdom and the United States.
Sikkim is a northeastern state situated within the borders of India.
Christa McAuliffe, a social studies teacher, began her role at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.

Ron Weasley is a central character in J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series, originating from the Weasley family, a magical British clan known for their financial struggles and large family size. He is Ronald Bilius Weasley, a Gryffindor student at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, and a close friend of Harry Potter. Ron is known for his loyalty, bravery, and occasional clumsiness. His character development throughout the series highlights his growth from a somewhat insecure and overshadowed younger brother to a confident and integral member of the Order of the Phoenix, playing a significant role in the fight against Lord Voldemort.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama movie, directed and written by Mike Binder, and produced by his brother Jack Binder. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and premiered on March 23, 2007.
Colin Kaepernick, born on November 3, 1987, is an American professional football quarterback. Currently, he is a free agent, meaning he is not under contract with any NFL team.

Sheryl Lee, in 2016, was featured in the film 'Café Society' and the Showtime revival of 'Twin Peaks', where she reprised her role as Laura Palmer. Simultaneously, Sheryl Lee Ralph, also in 2016, portrayed Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of 'Wicked'.
Matteo Renzi, born on 11 January 1975, is an Italian politician who held the position of Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado is a movie featuring an ensemble cast including Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

"Same Old Love" is a track from Selena Gomez's second studio album, Revival (2015). The album itself debuted at the top position on the Billboard 200 chart. The first three singles from Revival, "Good for You," "Same Old Love," and "Hands to Myself," all reached the number one spot on the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a television program hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal, or metal, is a subgenre of rock music that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s, primarily in the UK and US. The new wave of British heavy metal, which included bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon, further developed this genre in the late 1970s.

Ashton Kutcher transitioned from his initial roles to prominent appearances in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is a subsidiary of the Arcadia Group, which also manages other brands like Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins. It operates a network of high-street men's clothing stores across the United Kingdom, with a strong presence on numerous UK High Streets. Additionally, Topman has a significant footprint in Ireland, with outlets in six major cities and towns.

During the Industrial Revolution, Wales underwent significant transformation from an agrarian society to an industrial powerhouse, primarily due to the flourishing of mining and metallurgical sectors. The South Wales Coalfield's extensive exploitation led to a rapid population growth in Wales.

Tool, a band, has achieved significant recognition in the music industry. They have been honored with three Grammy Awards, an esteemed accolade in the music world. The band has also embarked on extensive worldwide tours, showcasing their talent to diverse audiences. Furthermore, they have produced albums that have consistently topped charts in multiple countries, demonstrating their global appeal and commercial success.
YouTube, an American video-sharing platform, is based in San Bruno, California. It is globally recognized as the second most visited website, according to Alexa Internet's web traffic analysis.
Sidse Babett Knudsen, born on 22 November 1968, is a Danish actress. She is active in theatre, television, and film, showcasing her versatility across these mediums.

Conrad Dunn made his film debut in the 1981 comedy Stripes, portraying the character Francis "Psycho" Soyer. Alongside him, other notable actors like John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold also secured their first significant film roles in this movie.
The film "Raees" features an ensemble cast including Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is a U.S.-based record label established in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts as its founders.
Trollhunters is a computer-animated fantasy television series, developed by Guillermo del Toro, and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You. It is exclusively available on Netflix.

The Armenian Genocide, also referred to as the Armenian Holocaust, was a systematic extermination campaign orchestrated by the Ottoman government, resulting in the death of approximately 1.5 million Armenians. This event primarily targeted Ottoman citizens residing within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, Turkey. The Ottoman government also engaged in similar genocidal policies against other indigenous Christian ethnic groups, including the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, who were subjected to the Assyrian and Greek genocides, respectively. Historians often view these atrocities as part of a unified genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British individual who has established himself as an actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born on August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the West Front of the U.S. Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, born on 20 October 1956, is an English filmmaker renowned for his work in directing, producing, screenwriting, and theatre direction. His notable film credits include 'Shallow Grave', 'Trainspotting', 'The Beach', '28 Days Later', 'Sunshine', 'Slumdog Millionaire', '127 Hours', and 'Steve Jobs'. 'The Beach', a 2000 adventure drama, was directed by Boyle and originated from Alex Garland's 1996 novel, with the screenplay adapted by John Hodge.

In the initial week following the release of the dress image, over 10 million tweets were generated, with users extensively discussing the dress using hashtags like #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.

Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar, born on 22 January 1917, was a distinguished British Army officer. He held the honorary title of 'MC and bar', signifying his meritorious conduct and additional military service. He passed away on 11 June 2006.

Advertising is a type of marketing communication that uses either audio or visual means to convey a sponsored, nonpersonal message. Its primary purpose is to promote or sell a product, service, or idea.

The 2001 film, "The Others," garnered significant acclaim, winning eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director. Notably, it was the first English-language film to secure the Best Film Award at the Goyas, despite being entirely in English with no Spanish dialogue. The film was also recognized at the Saturn Awards, winning for Best Director, Best Writing (shared with Amenábar), and Best Performance by a Younger Actor (Alakina Mann). Additionally, it won three Saturn Awards: Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman), and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).

Ralph Fults, born on January 23, 1911, and passed away on March 16, 1993, was a notorious Depression-era outlaw who was closely linked with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow, collectively known as the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, born Lhamo Thondup on 6th July 1935, is the current spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism. He was born in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet, which was then part of Qinghai province, Republic of China. He was identified as the reincarnation of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and officially recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama in 1939 near Bumchen town. Following the 1959 Tibetan uprising, the Dalai Lama sought refuge in India, where he continues to reside as a political exile.

Miracle at St. Anna is a WWII film primarily set in Italy, focusing on four African-American soldiers from the 92nd Infantry Division, known as the Buffalo Soldiers. They find refuge in a Tuscan village, forming a strong bond with the local residents. The narrative unfolds through a frame story, where one of the soldiers recounts his experiences in 1980s New York, providing a retrospective perspective on the events.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born on November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat. She held the position of the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

Home for the Holidays (1995 film) features an ensemble cast including Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, spent her formative years in the city before relocating to Texas, and subsequently to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg, born in Lawton, Oklahoma, and raised in Anaheim, California, developed a deep fascination with the ocean during his childhood. Alongside this, he cultivated an interest in art.

Mendicant lifestyle is prevalent in various religious orders, such as Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, Sufi Islam's dervishes, Jainism's monastic orders, and Buddhism's monastic communities. A monk, derived from the Greek'monachos' meaning'single' or'solitary', is an individual who embraces religious asceticism through monastic living, either independently or alongside other monks. Monks can either commit to serving all living beings or opt for asceticism, voluntarily withdrawing from mainstream society to engage in prayer and contemplation.
The Mod Squad, a crime drama series, aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an impending American film that combines elements of science fiction, fantasy, western, and horror genres. It is directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona, the 48th state of the U.S., is situated in the southwestern region, being the sixth largest and the 14th most populous. It gained statehood on February 14, 1912, making it the last of the contiguous states. Approximately one-quarter of Arizona's land is occupied by Indian reservations, home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, with the Navajo Nation being the largest, encompassing over 300,000 citizens, both within Arizona and the U.S. as a whole.
Smriti Mandhana, born on 18th July 1996, is an Indian female cricketer who represents the Indian women's cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born on 15 April 1990 in Paris, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was raised in Oxfordshire and attended the Dragon School. Watson further honed her acting skills by training at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.

Angela Bassett initiated her film career in the mid-1980s, following her academic pursuits. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University and a Master of Fine Arts degree from a drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest accolade bestowed by NASA, presented by the U.S. President on the recommendation of NASA's Administrator. This prestigious award is given to astronauts who demonstrate exceptional achievements during their space missions under NASA's supervision. Notably, Frank Frederick Borman, II, a retired Colonel in the USAF, was one of the recipients of this medal.
The Saw film franchise has collectively earned more than $873 million at the global box office.
Down with Love is a 2003-released romantic comedy movie.
Paul Nicholls is a renowned actor, primarily recognized for his portrayal of Joe Wicks in the BBC series 'EastEnders' and as DS Sam Casey in the ITV series 'Law & Order : UK'.
The 2011 French action film, "Colombiana," was co-written and produced by Luc Besson, and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was a member of the principal cast in the Netflix original series Marco Polo, which concluded on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is renowned for several key industries and cultural aspects. These include horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal mining, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco production, bluegrass music, college basketball, and the iconic fast-food chain, Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Boyhood is a 2014 film that chronicles the life of Mason Evans, Jr., portrayed by Ellar Coltrane, from ages six to eighteen. The narrative unfolds over a decade, capturing his growth and experiences as he navigates childhood and adolescence in Texas with his divorced parents, played by Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke.
The 2016 film, Hush, was produced by Trevor Macy under his production company, Intrepid Pictures. Additionally, it was co-produced by Jason Blum through his Blumhouse Productions label.

The Penibaetic System, also known as the Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain range systems within the Baetic System, situated in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonzo (apparel) provides a comprehensive range of men's clothing, including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman, a subsidiary of the Arcadia Group, operates a vast network of high-street men's clothing stores across the United Kingdom and Ireland, with outlets in six major cities and towns. The Arcadia Group also owns other brands like Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins.
"Roar" is a track from Katy Perry's fourth studio album, Prism (2013). It was the initial single from this album, released on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, registered as Saturn LLC, was founded on January 7, 1985, as a subsidiary of General Motors.

The Armenian Genocide, also referred to as the Armenian Holocaust, was a systematic extermination of approximately 1.5 million Armenians, predominantly Ottoman citizens, by the Ottoman government during 1915. This event is now recognized as a genocide by many, but Turkey, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, disputes this label, maintaining that the term 'genocide' is inaccurate for the mass killings that occurred.

Muslims hold the belief that the Quran, their holy scripture, was orally communicated by God to Prophet Muhammad by the angel Gabriel (Jibril). This revelation occurred progressively over a span of about 23 years, starting from 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40 years old, and ending in 632 CE, the year of Muhammad's demise.

The human brain, a key component of the central nervous system, is divided into three main parts: the cerebrum, the brainstem, and the cerebellum. The cerebrum, the largest section, houses numerous significant structures beneath its cerebral cortex. These include the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (such as the amygdala and hippocampus), claustrum, various basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting, a 2017 British comedy-drama film, is centered in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American television network that caters to a family audience. Its programming encompasses a wide range of genres, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and various other features.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, known as "The Don," was a distinguished Australian cricketer, celebrated for his exceptional batting skills, often considered the greatest in the sport's history. Despite his reclusive nature during his later years, his influence and status as a national icon remained significant. His enduring legacy was recognized even after his retirement in 1948, with Prime Minister John Howard, in 2001, proclaiming him the "greatest living Australian."

Margaret Thatcher, born on 13 October 1925, was a prominent British politician who served as Prime Minister from 1979 to 1990 and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century and the first woman to hold this position. Thatcher's political career began when she defeated Edward Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election in 1975, making her the first woman to lead a major political party in the UK.

Macho Man Randy Savage, born Randy Poffo on November 15, 1952, was a renowned American professional wrestler and color commentator. He gained significant fame during his tenure in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). His ring name, "Macho Man," is synonymous with his charismatic and dominant wrestling persona. He passed away on May 20, 2011.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an acclaimed American singer, songwriter, and actor. His career has spanned more than five decades.

EA Black Box, originally known as Black Box Games, was a video game development company established in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, in 1998. The company was founded by ex-employees of Radical Entertainment. Later, it was acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae, also known as Baia Baia, was an ancient Roman coastal resort situated on the northwestern shore of the Gulf of Naples in Italy. It was a mineral springs destination, positioned under the shadow of Mount Vesuvius. The town of Herculaneum, a significant Roman settlement, was destroyed by volcanic eruptions in 79 AD. Its ruins are now part of the commune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy. Nearby, notable cultural and historical sites include the Palace of Caserta and the ancient Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. The passage also highlights the existence of numerous ancient ruins worldwide, ranging from China, the Indus valley, Judea, Zimbabwe, the Mediterranean basin (including Greek, Egyptian, and Roman sites), and the Americas (Incan and Mayan sites).

No Country for Old Men is a suspenseful drama film from 1980, set in the desolate West Texas landscape. The central character is a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran, portrayed by Tommy Lee Jones. Jones is also known for his roles as former Texas Ranger Woodrow F. Call in Lonesome Dove, Agent K in Men in Black, Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in No Country for Old Men, the antagonist Two-Face in Batman Forever, terrorist William Strannix in Under Siege, a Texas Ranger in Man of the House, rancher Pete Perkins in The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (where he also directed), CIA Director Robert Dewey in Jason Bourne, and Warden Dwight McClusky in Natural Born Killers.

Palo Alto is a charter city situated in the northwest part of Santa Clara County, California, within the San Francisco Bay Area of the U.S. Its name, derived from Spanish, translates to "tall tree," reflecting its geographical position as a tall, distinctive landmark.

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born on July 22, 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian. He is notably known for his role in the animated film "Finding Dory," directed by Andrew Stanton and co-directed by Angus MacLane. The screenplay was penned by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a system that converts text into a sequence of tones, lights, or clicks, which can be deciphered by a trained listener or observer without needing specialized equipment. It enhances communication speed by adjusting character lengths inversely to their English frequency. Unlike voice, Morse code is less affected by poor signal conditions, yet remains human-readable without decoding tools. This method is commonly used by amateur radio repeaters for voice communications and is favored in emergencies due to its simplicity and adaptability for improvised, easily switchable transmission methods.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born on March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake occurred in northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 9:47 PM UTC, with a magnitude of 6.5. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km long mountain range, situated along the Afghan-Pakistan border, extending from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan. This range is renowned for its numerous high snow-capped peaks, with Tirich Mir or Terichmir, located in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, being the highest at 7708 meters.
In 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students, with the majority residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand encompassing various sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and media assets worldwide, all managed or partly owned by the Murdoch family. Rupert Murdoch, as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate, holds comprehensive control over these entities. Following the conglomerate's split on 28 June 2013, Murdoch and his family continue to own 21st Century Fox and News Corp through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is an American women's apparel brand that specializes in creating clothing with a tomboyish aesthetic.
Bessie Smith, born on April 15, 1894, was an influential American blues singer who passed away on September 26, 1937.

Speech recognition (SR) is a specialized area within computational linguistics, focusing on creating methodologies and technologies that allow computers to convert spoken language into written text. This field integrates expertise from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.

Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875, was an English individual who excelled in multiple fields. He was an occultist, delving into the mystical and spiritual, and a ceremonial magician, practicing rituals and spells. Crowley was also a prolific poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer, showcasing his versatility across literature and adventure. He passed away on 1 December 1947.
Poldark is a television series, originating from both Britain and America, which premiered on BBC One on March 8, 2015.

Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, a romantic film, was released on 20 October 1995. It features lead actors Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol. The movie was filmed in India, London, and Switzerland, spanning from September 1994 to August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born on May 14, 1961, is a renowned English actor and director. Separately, Tim Roth, born on December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and the sole founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band, Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal, in 1986, tied the knot with professional tennis player John McEnroe. Their union resulted in the birth of three children.

Sean Penn, an acclaimed actor, has won two Academy Awards. His first was for his role in the 2003 mystery drama Mystic River, and the second for his portrayal in the 2008 biographical drama Milk. Penn's career began with a film debut in Taps (1981) and expanded with notable roles in the 1980s, such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982). He gained significant recognition for his performances in crime dramas like At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn's breakthrough role came with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning him his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received further nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), before finally winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River. His subsequent film, the 2007 biographical drama Into the Wild, earned him two more Academy Award nominations.

The Earth's primordial atmosphere and ocean were likely formed through volcanic outgassing, but it was devoid of oxygen, making it harmful to most modern life, including humans. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, enabling liquid water to exist on the surface. Plate tectonics remains a key factor in shaping Earth's oceans, continents, and the life they support. Human activities, now dominant in the biosphere, significantly impact the atmosphere and Earth's surface systems, such as the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, soil productivity, and air/water quality. Notably, water covers 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as Godthåb, is the capital and the most populous city in Greenland. It serves as the administrative center of the municipality of Sermersooq.

"How to Train Your Dragon 2" is a motion picture directed by Dean DeBlois and penned by him as well. The film features an ensemble voice cast, including Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig. Notably, the original cast from the first film reprises their roles. New additions to the cast are Cate Blanchett and Djimon Hounsou, who voice Valka and Drago, respectively.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed and written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake. The movie features Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce. It's a parody of the 1950s and 1960s sex comedies, specifically referencing Doris Day and Rock Hudson's films: Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961), and Send Me No Flowers (1964). The film was first aired in Taiwan on China Television (CTV) from January 31, 2010, to May 23, 2010, every Sunday from 10:00 PM to 11:30 PM. It also aired on Gala Television (GTV) Variety Show/CH 28 from February 2, 2010, to May 30, 2010, every Sunday from 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM.
The Paris album, named after its creator, Paris Hilton, blends a diverse range of musical styles. These include reggae, soul, and pop rock, showcasing a fusion of genres in its production.

Stripes, a 1981 American comedy film, was directed by Ivan Reitman and featured an ensemble cast including Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. Notable debuts were made by John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, Judge Reinhold, Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton in their early film roles.

Janelle Monáe, born on December 1, 1985, is an American multi-talented artist. She is recognized for her work as a singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She operates her own record label, Wondaland Arts Society, and is also signed to Atlantic Records.

Jewell, a singer, gained prominence primarily through her rendition of the song "Love or Lust" from the movie Deep Cover, directed by Bill Duke. Additionally, she is recognized for her background vocals in numerous iconic West Coast rap tracks, including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."

The University of Mississippi has a significant local student body, with approximately 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of all students originating from the state of Mississippi. Additionally, 23% of its student body identifies as a minority. The university attracts international students from 90 different countries.
The Mighty Ducks film was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions, and was subsequently distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy, known for her role as Jenny Matrix in the popular web series Video Game High School (2012-2014), has since expanded her acting portfolio. In 2015, she co-starred in the Lifetime series Unreal as Anna Martin. Currently, she is portraying Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren, born on December 5, 1782, was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. He was a prominent member of the Democratic Party and held significant roles such as the eighth Vice President (1833-1837) and tenth Secretary of State (1829-1831) under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren played a crucial part in Jackson's 1828 election campaign, supporting and organizing for him. After serving as Governor of New York for two months, he resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, following his resignation as Secretary of State, Jackson appointed Van Buren as American minister to Britain, a move that helped resolve the Petticoat affair.

Camden, New Jersey is the location of Rutgers University-Camden, established in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School. Additionally, it houses the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which commenced operations in 2012.

Michigan, situated in the Great Lakes and Midwestern areas of the U.S., is the tenth most populous state and the eleventh in total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. It's unique as it comprises two peninsulas, contributing to its significant recreational boating opportunities. Michigan is a constituent political entity of the United States.

Penguin Books, established in the 1930s, significantly transformed the publishing industry by introducing affordable paperbacks, priced at sixpence, which were sold in popular high street stores like Woolworths. This move democratized access to high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction, making them available to a broader, mass market audience.
The 2008 film "Australia" was primarily filmed in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is a renowned American figure in country music, known for his roles as a singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist. He significantly contributed to the global popularity of country music.

French Montana, a rapper, released his debut studio album titled 'Excuse My French' in 2014.

'Excuse My French' is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film is based on Salama's personal experiences at a public middle school in Egypt following his return from Saudi Arabia.

The film, initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, required Salama to modify the script while maintaining its central theme of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough, in 2013, was a central figure in the South Korean-American independent dance film 'Make Your Move'. This movie was inspired by the classic Romeo and Juliet tale.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga, released in 2009 as part of her extended play 'The Fame Monster'. The song gained significant popularity after an unauthorized demo was leaked, with Gaga presenting the final version at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show. The single's cover art was also unveiled around the same time. It became a global hit, selling over 12 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling singles of all time.

Additionally, a 2011 independent film titled "Les Mauvais Romans" (Bad Romance in French) was released. This film is not directly related to Lady Gaga's music, but shares the same title as her hit song.

DreamWorks Animation, a renowned studio, has produced 34 feature films. These include popular franchises such as Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. Other notable releases are Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). Additionally, they've ventured into television with Trollhunters, an American computer-animated fantasy series created for Netflix, produced in collaboration with Guillermo del Toro and Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, born in 1966, is a renowned British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Christopher Livingstone "Chris" Eubank Jr., born in 1989, is also a British professional boxer. Chris Eubank Jr. has successfully held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, previously claiming the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Chris Eubank Jr. is ranked as the fifth-best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush, born on July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She gained prominence for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch, an Australian-British-American businessman, is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He is the younger son of media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, who previously held the positions of CEO and chairman of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate. Following the split of News Corporation into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on 28 June 2013, Rupert Murdoch continues to lead 21st Century Fox as its CEO and chairman.

In 2013, Gal Gadot was recognized as the second highest-earning actress/model in Israel, surpassing Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, but trailing behind Bar Refaeli. The majority of her earnings were derived from her acting career.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, commonly known as CCR, was an American rock band that operated primarily during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are typically identified through a radiographic examination, often called an x-ray.

The South Wales Coalfield, also known as Maes glo De Cymru in Welsh, is a significant geographical area in south Wales. It is particularly renowned for its extensive coal reserves, with the South Wales Valleys being the most notable coal-rich region within this area.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football tournament, initiated in 1962, by CONCACAF, the governing body for North and Central American and Caribbean football. Initially named the CONCACAF Champions' Cup, it is a competition featuring the top clubs from these regions.

Mary of Teck, widowed in 1936 after King George's death, ascended to the role of Queen Mother upon her eldest son Edward's ascension to the throne. However, Edward abdicated the same year to marry Wallis Simpson, a twice-divorced American socialite. Mary then supported her second son, Albert, who became King George VI, until his death in 1952. She passed away the following year, during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon, a film, achieved a worldwide box office gross of $181,674,817. This was achieved despite a production budget of $160 million, indicating a profitable performance.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was inaugurated in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton have both received this accolade three times, setting the record for the most wins in this category.

Human trafficking involves the illegal trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that forced labor alone generates around $150 billion annually, with 14.2 million people exploited for labor, 4.5 million for sexual exploitation, and 2.2 million in state-imposed forced labor as of 2014.
The 2011 film 'Rio' had a sequel titled 'Rio 2', which was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, also known as François Ier, was a significant figure in European history. He held the titles of Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife held the real power in these roles. Francis I was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death in 1547. He is famously remembered for his involvement in wars against Charles V, the Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, earning nicknames like "François au Grand Nez" (Francis of the Large Nose), "Grand Colas," and "Roi-Chevalier" (Knight-King). Despite his military efforts, these conflicts were unsuccessful. In response, Francis I formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman the Magnificent, a controversial move for a Christian king at the time. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a significant conflict during his reign, pitting him against Charles V.

Peking University, abbreviated as PKU, is a renowned, modern Chinese research university situated in Beijing. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, serving as China's initial modern national university. Initially functioning as the highest education administration ministry, it has since evolved into a leading higher learning institution in mainland China, consistently ranking at the top.
Lemmy, renowned for his distinctive appearance characterized by mutton chops, was celebrated for his unique gravelly voice and his signature bass playing style.

Global warming poses substantial threats to human society. These include the potential for diminished food security resulting from reduced crop yields, and the necessity for people to evacuate coastal regions due to escalating sea levels.

The 2008 film 'Australia' is a collaborative effort between Australian, American, and British filmmakers, directed by Baz Luhrmann. It features a star-studded cast including Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. The movie is a grand, historical romantic drama, showcasing the Australian outback during the 1930s.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, was a professional American football quarterback. He had a 13-year career in the National Football League, primarily for the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a variety of elements, primarily oral traditions like songs, legends, tales, proverbs, and jokes. It also incorporates weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices such as food-making and craft-making. These components collectively form the core of Canadian folklore.

The First Motion Picture Unit was responsible for creating over 400 films, primarily serving as propaganda and training materials. These films were distinguished by their dual purpose of being both informative and entertaining. Additionally, the unit trained combat cameramen and produced training films.

James Jones, a renowned author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel, 'From Here to Eternity', which was subsequently adapted into a film and a television series. In the realm of basketball, James Jones, a player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State accolades. His basketball career includes three NBA championships, two with the Miami Heat and one with the Cleveland Cavaliers. Notably, he and his teammate LeBron James made it to the NBA Finals for an unprecedented seventh consecutive year in 2017. During the 2007-08 season, he ranked third in the NBA in three-point percentage and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, Humphrey Bogart was recognized by the American Film Institute as the top male star in Classic American cinema.
Trollhunters is a computer-animated fantasy television series, produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You, and created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix.
Shane McMahon, a prominent figure in WWE, resigned from his position in 2009, with the resignation becoming effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker, a renowned English actor, is celebrated for his portrayal of the fourth Doctor in the long-running science fiction series Doctor Who, spanning from 1974 to 1981, a period longer than any other actor's tenure. Beyond acting, he has lent his voice to various projects, including the narration of the comedy series Little Britain. His vocal talents have also been utilized in commercials, video games, audiobooks, and additional television series.
Angelsberg is a compact town situated within the administrative area of Fischbach, located in the heart of Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is primarily known for its ongoing cleanup project. However, it also functions as a commercial nuclear power plant, specifically the Columbia Generating Station. Additionally, it houses several research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a high-ranking White House official, appointed directly by the President, who functions as the primary spokesperson for the U.S. executive branch, particularly the President, senior officials, and policies. Despite not needing Senate approval, the role is highly visible due to regular media interactions, making it a significant, non-Cabinet position.

Kentucky, referred to as the "Bluegrass State," is named after its abundant bluegrass pastures, a result of its fertile soil. The state's central region, the Bluegrass Region, is home to its two largest cities, Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is renowned for horse racing, bourbon production, coal mining, the historic My Old Kentucky Home site, automobile manufacturing, tobacco cultivation, bluegrass music, college basketball, and the iconic Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Broken Bridges, a 2006 film, features Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston in its cast. Notably, Kelly Preston, who also appeared in The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and this film, is a notable actress in the cast.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American artist known for her work as a singer, songwriter, and rapper. She was previously stylized as Ke$ha.

On May 5, 2017, two versions of the song "Despacito" were simultaneously released. The first was an electronic version, produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA. The second was an urban version, produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event, initially aired on closed-circuit television from 1983 to 1986 by the NWA, and later transitioned to pay-per-view in 1987 by WCW. The WWF's Survivor Series, scheduled for Thanksgiving in 1987, demanded exclusive cable carrier rights, leading to Starrcade's shift to pay-per-view. The event, including the 1983-1986 closed-circuit television broadcasts, was rated TV-MA due to its violent content, particularly the 1997 "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum, T.A. The 1997 Starrcade marked the fifteenth annual pay-per-view event.
Veeru Devgan is a professional in the Indian film industry, specifically in Bollywood, specializing in stunt and action choreography, as well as film direction.
Star Trek: Discovery is the inaugural series exclusively produced for the streaming platform, marking its debut after Star Trek: Enterprise's conclusion in 2005.

Terry Crews is a former NFL defensive end and linebacker, having played for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. Additionally, he participated in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut album by American rapper French Montana, released in 2014. In contrast, Excuse My French is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, inspired by his personal experiences at a public middle school in Egypt following his return from Saudi Arabia.

Ben Drew, born as Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew on October 22, 1983, is a British hip hop artist, actor, film director, and producer, known by his stage name Plan B or Ben Drew.

A floppy disk, often referred to as a floppy, diskette, or simply disk, is a type of magnetic storage medium encased in a rectangular plastic housing. This housing is lined with fabric to prevent dust accumulation. The disk itself is made of a thin, flexible magnetic material.

Guatemala faced persistent instability and civil conflict from the mid to late 19th century. A significant period of this was a brutal civil war (1960-1996), where the government, supported by the United States, battled leftist rebels. This conflict was marked by grave human rights violations, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population, orchestrated by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged tools primarily utilized for grasping and holding objects. In non-medical contexts, they are often interchangeably called tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The series "The Closer" commenced its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011. Prior to this, it had concluded its sixth season as cable television's most-watched drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the main character in the ABC television series Lost, which aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, across six seasons totaling 121 episodes. The show's first season attracted approximately 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey, born on November 4, 1969, is an American actor renowned for transitioning to dramatic roles since 2011. His notable films include The Lincoln Lawyer (2011), Bernie (2011), Killer Joe (2011), The Paperboy (2012), Mud (2012), Magic Mike (2012), The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Dallas Buyers Club (2013), Interstellar (2014), The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones (both 2016). In the 2012 film Mud, he co-starred alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer, renowned for his literary works such as 'Deep Blues', also made significant contributions to music journalism through articles for the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine. His professional involvement extends to producing blues recordings and creating the soundtrack for the film 'Deep Blues'. Additionally, he was a clarinetist in the 1960s band, the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is renowned for leading the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial, following his father Gutzon Borglum's death in 1941. Gutzon Borglum had initiated the project in 1927 and oversaw its execution until his demise in 1941. Lincoln Borglum, his son, took over the project's leadership post his father's passing.

The film "Underdog" was directed by Frederik Du Chau and penned by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It features an ensemble cast including Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton. The voice cast comprises Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 (TV series) revolves around a group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha. They are the initial inhabitants of "The Ark," a space habitat, who return to Earth following a catastrophic nuclear war. The narrative also centers on Clarke's mother, Dr. Abby Griffin, and two key figures from the Ark's council: Marcus Kane and Thelonious Jaha, who is the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite facing financial challenges due to its innovative approach, is acknowledged as a highly successful and impactful humanitarian initiative. It significantly raised awareness and substantial funds for the cause, serving as a model for subsequent events like Live Aid. The concert's influence extends to offering valuable lessons and inspiration for future aid projects.
Mani Ratnam, recognized as a significant figure in Indian cinema by the media, is acknowledged for transforming the Tamil film industry and broadening the scope of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was introduced by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. This doctrine was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln (Republican) and Stephen Douglas (Democratic), known as the Lincoln-Douglas Debates or The Great Debates of 1858. These debates were significant as they centered around the contentious issue of slavery, attracting large crowds from neighboring states due to its national importance.

Easy A, a 2010 American teen comedy film, was directed by Will Gluck and penned by Bert V. Royal. The movie features an ensemble cast including Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an acclaimed American author renowned for her gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. Her professional writing journey commenced with the publication of 'Interview with the Vampire' in 1976, while residing in California. She subsequently penned sequels to this novel in the 1980s. Initially, her works received mixed reviews, but her popularity grew significantly in the 1980s. Rice was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until Stan's death in 2002 due to brain cancer at the age of 60.

Camden, a city in Camden County, New Jersey, had a population of 77,344 in 2010, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. Historically, its population was predominantly European immigrants at the start of the 20th century. A city is defined as a large, enduring human settlement.
