Bret Easton Ellis, a renowned author, also penned the screenplay for the 2013 film 'The Canyons'. This film, directed by Paul Schrader, is classified as an erotic thriller-drama. The movie, written by Ellis, received significant criticism.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven public debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Party senator. These debates took place in seven different towns across the state of Illinois.

Homer, identified as Ὅμηρος (hómɛːros) or Hómēros by ancient Greeks, is the renowned author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two foundational epic poems in ancient Greek literature. In contrast, Joe R. Lansdale, an American author, penned the mystery/suspense novel titled 'The Thicket'.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and renowned sniper, was tragically killed on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range in Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-member band formed in 2001, featuring Chris Cornell from Soundgarden as the lead singer and rhythm guitarist, and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk, known for his drumming in Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07), also co-founded Rage with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991. As of 2016, Wilk is part of the supergroup Prophets of Rage, alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, comprises rapper and vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist and backing vocalist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe, born on December 1, 1985, is an American artist who excels in singing, songwriting, acting, and modeling. She operates under her own record label, Wondaland Arts Society, and is also signed to Atlantic Records. Her debut full-length studio album, 'The ArchAndroid', was released in 2010. This album is a concept piece, serving as a sequel to her initial EP, and was initially distributed by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale, a novel, was written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence, located in East Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana, serves as the parish seat of the United States. The town is home to the University of Mississippi, where approximately 55% of its undergraduate students and 60% of all students originate from Mississippi. Additionally, 23% of the student body are minorities, and the university attracts international students from 90 different countries.
In July 2016, the series 'Flaked' was renewed for a six-episode second season, with the premiere scheduled for June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly twice, from 1784 to 1785 and 1798 to 1799. He was appointed as New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791. Burr's most significant political role was as a U.S. senator from New York, serving from 1791 to 1797. His career culminated when he became the Vice President of the United States.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft, initially developed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s for the Soviet space program. Its primary function was to launch Soyuz spacecraft, initially with 8 unmanned test flights, followed by the first 19 manned launches. The name 'Soyuz' translates to 'Union' in Russian, reflecting its role as a symbol of Soviet unity. It succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was initially intended for the Soviet manned lunar programs. Despite its initial purpose, Soyuz remains in service today.
Steve Ditko, a renowned comic book artist, honed his skills under the tutelage of Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

In 2000, Rage Against the Machine experienced internal strife over the band's direction, causing vocalist Zack de la Rocha to depart. This led to the band's disbandment. De la Rocha embarked on a quiet solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave, a rock supergroup featuring Chris Cornell from Soundgarden. Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007. In 2007, Rage Against the Machine reunited for a performance at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, marking their first collaboration in seven years. Their fourth studio album, 'Renegades', was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a market-weighted index tracking 30 financially robust companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Among these, Tata Motors is a prominent constituent, also listed on the BSE, National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially known as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost nation on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th most populous country globally, with approximately 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the ninth most populous in Asia. Vietnam shares its borders with China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced rapid economic growth, ranking among the highest globally, and in 2011, it held the highest position in the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Despite this, Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states, officially upholding communism.
Dreamer, a 2005 American sports drama film, was directed and written by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh, an Indian socialist revolutionary, was born on 23 March 1907 and tragically executed at the age of 23. His notable acts of defiance against the British in India, though brief, garnered him a significant following, transforming him into a revered folk hero of the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana, a newcomer in Bollywood, initiated his acting career with the 2016 film "Dangal," a biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari. The movie, "Dangal," is based on the true story of Mahavir Singh Phogat, a wrestling coach, and his daughters' journey in the wrestling world.

James VI and I, born on 19 June 1566, reigned as King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and as King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. He ruled both Scotland and England in personal union, meaning each kingdom maintained its own parliament, judiciary, and laws, while being governed by him. A significant challenge during his reign in England was the conflict with Parliament. James was a proponent of a unified parliament for both Scotland and England.

Danielle Cormack, born on 26th December 1970, is a prominent New Zealand-based stage and screen actress. She gained fame as part of the initial cast of the long-running soap opera Shortland Street. Cormack is also recognized for her roles in television series such as Xena: Warrior Princess as Ephiny, The Cult as Cynthia Ross, and Legend of the Seeker as Shota. Her film credits include Separation City (2009) and the Australian series Rake. In recent years, she notably portrayed Kate Leigh, a Sydney underworld figure, in Underbelly: Razor. Her most significant recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years until 2016.

Robert Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American professional in graphic design, directing, and photography. He gained significant recognition for his extensive collaborations with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is a notable actor who has featured in numerous films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. He also co-starred in Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and penned by Spade and Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16, 1958, is an accomplished American actress.

Artpop, Lady Gaga's 2013 album, garnered mixed critical reception. Despite this, it achieved significant commercial success. It launched at the top of the U.S. Billboard 200 chart with 258,000 copies sold in its first week, marking Gaga's second consecutive number-one record in the U.S. The album sold a total of 757,000 copies in the U.S. and 2.3 million worldwide, making it the ninth best-selling album of 2013.

In 2006, John Frusciante, a guitarist for the Red Hot Chili Peppers, released his fifth and final album with the band, titled 'Stadium Arcadium'. This album marked the end of his tenure with the group, as he officially departed in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, serving as Prime Minister, introduced policies that are now recognized as Thatcherism. Despite her polarizing nature, she is widely regarded as one of the most significant and impactful British politicians, with ongoing debates surrounding her political legacy.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. His notable contributions extend beyond music, as he has also ventured into writing. He regularly pens weekly columns on diverse topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, a renowned English actor, has expanded his career beyond acting into narration. He has provided voiceovers for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital city of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the third most populous city in the country, with approximately 800,000 residents in its administrative center. The metropolitan area surrounding Valencia spans from 1.7 to 2.5 million inhabitants, making it the third largest metropolitan area in Spain. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous region within Spain, with Valencia serving as its largest city and metropolitan hub.
Buffy Summers, a significant character, was first depicted in a film where she was played by Kristy Swanson. Later, Sarah Michelle Gellar took over the role in the television series.
Make It or Break It, a television series, concluded on May 14, 2012, with its third season serving as the final installment. The series' end was officially announced on April 26, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a multidisciplinary area within computational linguistics that focuses on creating technologies for converting spoken language into written text. It integrates linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. SR applications span across various domains, including voice-controlled interfaces like voice dialing and call routing, controlling smart home devices, searching for specific content in audio, simple data entry, preparing structured documents, speech-to-text processing in applications like word processors and emails, and aircraft communication (Direct Voice Input). The field's progress is marked by an increase in academic publications and widespread industry adoption of deep learning techniques for speech recognition systems. Notable companies utilizing deep learning in their speech recognition technologies are Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (born January 26, 1952, died January 4, 2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970, initially naming it the Golden State Comic Book Convention. Alf, along with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, played a pivotal role in establishing this event, which later evolved into the San Diego Comic Book Convention. He served as its chairman from the inception in 1970 until his passing in 2012.
Fist of Legend is a reimagined version of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, featuring Bruce Lee in the principal role.

In the Turkish Open, Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy, a four-time major winner, shot a third consecutive 67, tying the lead with South Africa's Erik van Zyl at 16 under par. McIlroy, who aims for his first title since May, included an eagle on the 12th hole. Despite starting the day level par after 10 holes, he bounced back with birdies on the 11th and 13th, culminating in an eagle from four feet. McIlroy, who had to miss several tournaments due to a left ankle ligament rupture in July, returned to play in the Frys.com Open and the Turkish Open. He currently leads England's Danny Willett by 271 points in the Race to Dubai, with three events left. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland, who were initially tied for second, now stand fifth and seventh, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the al-Wefaq political society, advocates for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, emphasizing the necessity of concrete solutions from the government. He supports Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, seen as a reformist, over the hardline Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, who opposes dialogue due to fears of further concessions. Despite the opposition's loss of faith in mainstream parties, Sheikh Salman believes in working with reformists within the royal family, particularly the Crown Prince, who previously agreed on a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy. He criticizes the US and UK for not applying sufficient pressure on Bahrain regarding human rights and democratic practices, urging clearer and more direct US policy under Secretary Kerry and public UK stance against violence and abuses. Sheikh Salman maintains al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations, despite their ban, and calls for the release of 13 imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, whose support is crucial for the success of the dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. His funeral was private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood, a significant figure in the early-music movement, collaborated with numerous international orchestras. He established the AAM in 1973, leading it across six continents for nearly three decades. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's notable recordings include the 1980 Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, recognized as one of the top 20 recordings by BBC Music Magazine.

Hogwood's musical education began at Cambridge University, where he studied keyboard under esteemed professors. His career commenced as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner. He was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London and held prestigious positions as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society.

Beyond his conducting and teaching roles, Hogwood was an influential educator, serving as a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University. His colleagues and admirers, including Dame Emma Kirkby and David Thomas, praised his exceptional academic abilities, genial nature, and ability to make music speak for itself. They highlighted his role in nurturing future leading orchestra musicians.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases, marking the lowest number in a single 12-month period since 1976. This is half the figure from nine years prior. One case remained unresolved by the end of March 2016. The most common method of killing was a sharp instrument, specifically knives, accounting for 51% of homicides (29 cases). Alcohol and drugs were present in 31% of these cases, with 20 individuals identified as under the influence.

Justice Secretary Michael Matheson expressed optimism about the continued decline in homicides and violent crime, attributing it to education and enforcement efforts. He emphasized the need for ongoing support for at-risk communities and challenging irresponsible attitudes towards alcohol misuse and casual violence. The Scottish government plans to collaborate with various public services and invest in projects to guide young people away from violent lifestyles, while ensuring law enforcement and courts have adequate resources to address offenders.

However, Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman, Claire Baker, cautioned against over-enthusiasm, citing a history of revised homicide figures being upwardly adjusted. She also highlighted a 45-year high in sexual crime and a 27% increase in violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault, in the past year. The initial 2014-15 homicide count was 59, later revised to 62 after three cases were reclassified.

Bournemouth suffered a 2-1 defeat to Sunderland on Saturday, marking their first loss of the Premier League season. Dan Gosling's goal, their first in three matches, initially gave them the lead. Manager Eddie Howe expressed disbelief over the team's inability to convert their chances, stating that the lack of goals is hard to accept, despite creating numerous opportunities. Sunderland's goals were scored by Victor Anichebe and a penalty by Jermain Defoe, with Bournemouth unable to equalize even after Steven Pienaar's red card. Howe emphasized the importance of learning from such setbacks and moving forward.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's stance on managing migrant boat arrivals. Abbott asserts that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referring to Australia's policy of detaining and processing migrants attempting to reach its shores by sea, before resettling them in offshore camps. This policy has been criticized by the New York Times, which described it as "brutal," "inhumane," and "of dubious legality," contrasting it with Australia's historical welcoming of refugees. Abbott maintains that this policy has effectively halted boat arrivals.

Additionally, the passage highlights Abbott's controversial remarks comparing the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis. He stated that while the Nazis hid their evil, IS militants "boast about their evil." This comment drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups, with the Executive Council of Australian Jewry condemning it as "injudicious and unfortunate," emphasizing the fundamental difference between organized terrorism and state-sponsored genocide. Despite the backlash, Abbott defended his comments, asserting he was not comparing the two forms of evil.

The United States has accused Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, Syria's largest city in the north. The US has halted negotiations with Russia, citing Moscow's failure to uphold commitments under a ceasefire, which led to a resumption of heavy aerial bombardment after the truce's expiration. The main hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of Aleppo has been hit three times in a week, resulting in numerous civilian casualties, including children. Approximately 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo. The US State Department's spokesman, John Kirby, stated that Russia and the Syrian regime have been targeting critical infrastructure like hospitals and obstructing humanitarian aid. Russia denies involvement in a recent attack on a humanitarian aid convoy, attributing it to ground fire. In response to the US suspension of talks, Russia's foreign ministry spokeswoman, Maria Zakharova, expressed regret, accusing Washington of not meeting the agreement's humanitarian condition in Aleppo. Russia also criticized the US for not separating jihadist groups from moderate opposition forces. Despite the suspension, both nations will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent conflicts.

Downing Street supports a Policy Exchange report advocating for the sale of high-value vacant homes to generate £4.5bn annually, which could fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 social homes. This proposal, outlined in the "Ending Expensive Social Tenancies" report, aims to stimulate the economy and create the largest social house building program since the 1970s. Neil O'Brien, Policy Exchange's director, asserts that social housing should exist in expensive areas but not in their most luxurious parts, suggesting this could reduce the 1.8 million people currently on the social housing waiting list by about 500,000.

However, Labour opposes this plan, arguing that it exacerbates the housing crisis by driving out low-income families from affluent neighborhoods. Shadow housing minister Jack Dromey proposes using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes and employ unemployed builders to boost the construction industry. Critics warn that such a policy could lead to the "dramatic erosion" of mixed communities and the creation of segregated areas of wealth and poverty.

Policy Exchange estimates that 3.5% of the total social housing stock becomes vacant annually, with 28,500 properties available for sale each year, potentially raising £5.5bn. After debt repayment, this would amount to £4.5bn. The think tank claims that 73% of people, including social tenants, agree that people should not receive council houses worth more than the average local property.

The government, led by Housing Minister Grant Shapps, defends its approach, citing radical reforms to increase affordable housing construction and reduce social housing waiting lists. They've invested £19.5bn into an affordable housing program, which is expected to surpass expectations and deliver up to 170,000 homes. Councils are encouraged to offer fixed-term tenancies to ensure social housing goes to those most in need.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old resident of Swansea, passed away at his home last week amidst a measles outbreak that has resulted in 942 cases since November. Despite laboratory tests confirming a measles diagnosis following his death, an inquest has been opened and adjourned to conduct additional tests to ascertain if measles was the primary cause of his demise. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently recovered from asthma at Swansea's Morriston Hospital before developing a measles rash a few days after discharge. He sought medical attention for the rash on April 17, but was found dead the following morning. His mother, Angela Colfer, expressed confusion as no close family members, including his three-year-old daughter who is vaccinated, have measles. The outbreak has led to 83 hospitalizations, with further investigations ongoing to understand the source of his infection.

Vincent Hudson, aged 54, from Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offense involving an assault on a boy under 16, according to Cumbria Police. The incident is reported to have occurred in 2001. Hudson is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Guiseley, led by Neil Aspin, maintained their unbeaten streak in nine games, with their only goal scored by Jake Lawlor in the 15th minute. Gateshead, under Adam Lockwood, kept their own unbeaten record intact in five matches. The first half saw Guiseley take the lead with Lawlor's goal, while Gateshead's defender Liam Hogan and Guiseley's keeper Jonny Maxted made notable saves. The second half started with Guiseley's Jordan Preston and Gateshead's Gus Mafuta making substitutions. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wesley York scored from a curling shot. Guiseley responded with substitutions, including Michael Rankine and Adam Boyes, and Gateshead's Luke Hannant entered the game. The match ended with a 1-1 draw, with Wesley York scoring for Gateshead and Jake Lawlor for Guiseley. Simon Walton from Guiseley and Gus Mafuta from Gateshead were both shown yellow cards during the game.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the club's owner, intends to upgrade two stands to enhance the seating capacity, as an alternative to constructing a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is currently facing a delay due to a town green application. Steve Lansdown, the majority shareholder, announced the club's plan to commence the stand redevelopment at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday. The project received council approval in November. Lansdown stated that they will finalize the section 106 agreement soon, following which they will have six weeks to wait for the judicial review period. If the club successfully navigates through March without any judicial review, they will proceed with the redevelopment, starting in May, to provide supporters with a clear timeline and certainty.

Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, UK, has halted operations following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) confirmed that the April 1st tremor, centered near Poulton-le-Fylde, shares a similar location and mechanism with a 2.3 magnitude tremor on April 1st. Cuadrilla's CEO, Mark Miller, stated that the suspension is a precautionary measure, and they will analyze the collected data from the BGS before deciding on resuming operations. The BGS is also monitoring fracking activities in the region as a precaution. The process of fracking involves injecting pressurized water into shale rocks to release gas, which can potentially cause earthquakes. The BGS explained that any process involving the injection of pressurized water into rocks can lead to rock fracturing and subsequent seismic activity. The April 1st quake was felt by at least one person and occurred approximately 2km from the drilling site, with data from nearby instruments indicating a depth of around 2km. The BGS noted that the April 1st event shares similar characteristics with the previous tremor, suggesting a consistent pattern.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool who has performed in the city center for over three decades, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court. The charge stemmed from his use of a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes during a performance in April 2015. Carpenter claimed the banner was a tribute to the Hillsborough victims, not an attempt to collect funds. He had permission from the campaign's chairman, Kenneth Derbyshire, to design and display the banner, but was instructed not to use it for fundraising. Carpenter was cleared of two other fraud charges. He will be sentenced in January.

In a Championship match, Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers (QPR) at Loftus Road. Ipswich's goals were scored by Luke Varney, Tom Lawrence, and Cole Skuse. QPR's Alex Smithies, their goalkeeper, made significant errors, including a misplaced clearance leading to Varney's goal and a missed save on Skuse's long-range shot. Despite Ipswich's dominance in the game, QPR's defense was portrayed as lacking mental toughness, with manager Ian Holloway expressing disappointment. Ipswich's manager, Mick McCarthy, praised Luke Varney's performance and attributed the win to QPR's mistakes. The win elevated Ipswich to 14th place, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich's attackers, such as Tom Lawrence and Cole Skuse, had several near-misses, including a header against the post by Sandro late in the game.

23-year-old Wells demonstrated exceptional performance in the T20 Blast last season, amassing 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a high strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the club's progress, noting that the coaching staff foster an environment conducive to elite performance, which motivates the team members.

The Reds, currently ranked fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive victory by defeating third-ranked Chinnor 29-12. The team's strong performance was attributed to the front row and front five, who made over 70 tackles, according to Churcher. The Reds' next eight matches will be against teams positioned below them in the league, along with league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher acknowledged that while the Chinnor match wasn't flawless, it demonstrated resilience and emotional strength. He emphasized the need for his team to maintain this momentum, warning that any slip-up could render their recent success meaningless.

Nazrul, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi man, has been arrested for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun in a convent attack in Ranaghat town on 14 March. This is the sixth arrest in the case. Initially, five other suspects were apprehended, and all identified Nazrul as the perpetrator. Nazrul, who fled to Bangladesh after the incident, was traced back to Kolkata and arrested at a railway station following a tip-off. The attack also involved the theft of money from the convent school and the ransacking of the building. The nun was subsequently raped in the convent. This incident sparked widespread outrage and protests across India.

This interactive video, featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discusses key factors influencing consumer choices in the UK. These factors include the introduction of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports, which significantly altered the types of products available and popular among consumers. The video further delves into the evolving ownership and ranking of major UK brands. For those with older browsers, a non-interactive version of the content is provided below. Additional resources for further reading are also linked, including information on foreign ownership in China, tips for freezing food, and the BBC Good Food's annual survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK.

Two separate incidents have occurred in Scotland, one in Sandyhills on September 15 and the other in Stranraer on September 22. In both cases, elderly women were deceived by individuals posing as representatives from BT. The fraudsters claimed to be addressing technical issues with the victims' internet services. They managed to gain remote access to the victims' computers, enabling them to steal substantial sums of money. Police, including PC Siobhan Pellett, have warned the public about the alarming ease with which these scammers gain access to computers and the significant financial losses involved. They emphasize that no legitimate organizations, including banks and reputable businesses, request sensitive banking details or account numbers over the phone. The message is clear: never share such information over the telephone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, a third-placed Championship team, following his departure from Swinton Lions. He will oversee Featherstone's final league match against Toulouse on Saturday and their subsequent Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell expressed high praise for Duffy, acknowledging his exceptional coaching skills and the challenging circumstances he navigated at Swinton, where he was succeeded by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic, and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to a distress call at Sker Beach, close to Kenfig Nature Reserve. The individual, a rider, was found unconscious on wet sand, suffering from head injuries and extreme cold. Crewman Chris Page administered initial treatment before the rider was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.

The United Nations' World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), organized by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), approved a plan to allocate a portion of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system on Wednesday in Geneva. This decision was prompted by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which had 239 people on board, highlighting the inadequacies of the existing ground-based radar system. The new system, utilizing satellite tracking and automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, will enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. This move aims to address the 70% of the world's airspace currently uncovered by the current system. The ITU's Radiocommunication Bureau head, Francois Rancy, emphasized the potential for "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world." The Malaysian government had previously called for innovative real-time data transmission methods following the disappearance of MH370, which was last seen en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing and is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean. The ITU's Secretary-General, Houlin Zhao, praised the agency's swift response to global demands for enhanced flight tracking. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for implementing new tracking guidelines, which will mandate aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes, with more frequent updates in emergency situations.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at age five, has been found at 18, residing with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland, Ohio. Bobby, 53, was apprehended and is currently incarcerated at Cuyahoga County Jail, with a bail set at $250,000. The FBI, in collaboration with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity following a college application issue. His mother has been informed of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is also charged with tampering with records to secure a driver's license in 2012. Authorities had previously suspected Bobby as the potential culprit, given his false claim of taking Julian to pre-school in August 2002, after which he fled.

Firefighters conducted multiple inspections at a Duncan Street site over the past year due to fire safety concerns, with the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visiting nine times. The site, operated by Asset and Land Group, was found to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, according to GMFRS. However, following a blaze on 2 March, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's ability to accept waste, citing the potential environmental, residential, and transportation impacts of a fire. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective from 7 August, unless an appeal is filed. The fire's cause remains unknown. Asset and Land Group, the site operators, have not responded to requests for comment.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, introduced two bills in response to the Ukraine crisis, particularly focusing on Crimea. The first bill aims to facilitate the annexation of territories by Russia, suggesting that a referendum or a territorial leader's plea could trigger the process. This is based on the premise that a neighboring state needs to sign a treaty with Russia for such a transfer. The second bill expedites the issuance of Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly those in Crimea who wish to become Russian citizens. This bill waives state tax, residency requirements, and financial self-sufficiency checks, and allows for immediate citizenship after two months instead of a year. The initiative is seen as a support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians, who are deemed vulnerable in the current situation. Russian MPs, including celebrities, have visited Crimea to back these proposals.

McLaren, a renowned Formula One team with an impressive history of 182 wins, 12 world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, has experienced a significant decline since 2013. This slump began when the team lost its way in chassis design, despite retaining the Honda engine, which was crucial to their past triumphs. The current issue lies with the Honda power-unit, a stark contrast to their previous dominance, particularly in the 1988 season where they won 15 out of 16 races alongside Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost.

The team's last constructors' title was in 1998-99, following their partnership with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines. However, they were disqualified from winning the 2007 championship due to an illegal information breach with Ferrari. Subsequent years saw a series of ups and downs, with notable victories from Hamilton and Button in 2012, but no titles since 2008.

McLaren's history is marked by a recurring pattern of success and decline, starting with the team's establishment by Bruce McLaren in the 1960s. Their first title came in 1974, with Emerson Fittipaldi, and another followed in 1975 with James Hunt. However, they began to lose ground as technology advanced, similar to their current situation.

Ron Dennis, who took control in 1984, led the team to a period of dominance, the Honda era, and a Mercedes partnership. He returned in 2013 after a disappointing season, aiming to reverse the trend. Despite Fernando Alonso's return in 2015, driven by his belief in the Honda partnership, McLaren has struggled. Dennis remains optimistic, asserting that the team is close to breaking Mercedes' dominance and winning championships again. The current state of the team rests heavily on

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old resident of Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool's Old Swan area on 27 January. He was found injured and later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and are currently in police custody for questioning regarding the incident. Baker had just left Phoenix Gym, where he was working out, when he was shot while attempting to enter his car. Police suspect the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for approximately an hour. A silver Volkswagen Polo, which fled the scene at high speed, is being sought by investigators. The vehicle was seen traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Despite numerous CCTV captures, several potential witnesses have not yet come forward, with police emphasizing that their observations could be crucial to the ongoing investigation.

The passage discusses various online initiatives to make Christmas more spiritual without abandoning technology. Everyday Church Online, launched in the UK, offers virtual services every Sunday, accessible to a global congregation of 61 countries. The service includes a recorded sermon and a chat room, fostering a sense of community. Their first Christmas theme is Star Wars, with sermons titled "The Hope Awakens," drawing parallels between the franchise and Christmas.

Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play fantasy game developed by Scripture Union, is aimed at children aged 8-11. The game's objective is to restore light to a world plagued by darkness, using Bible-themed quests. Two new Bible-themed quests focus on finding the birth of baby Jesus.

Viral.de's 2010 video, "The Digital Story of Nativity," gained significant traction with nearly six million views, telling the nativity story through social media updates. The Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" has been viewed around 250,000 times, emphasizing the timelessness of Christmas.

Next Manga, known for distributing Old Testament stories in Manga form, has expanded into apps and e-books, including the Manga Messiah, available in 33 languages. The Arabic version was recently sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees.

Lastly, Christian groups are utilizing social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with their communities, focusing on sharing spiritual messages rather than detailed narratives. Kevin Bennett of Premier and Jules Middleton, a mission pastor, both agree that these platforms offer a modern approach to spreading the Gospel.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is evaluating a proposal to acquire 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for development. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed 320 hectares (800 acres) of alternative land. The inquiry has heard differing opinions from experts regarding the potential harm to local habitats and plant life due to the construction on the common land. Natural Resources Wales found it challenging to determine if the proposed replacement land is equally valuable, but it hasn't opposed the development. The developers' ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity, attributing this to nearby habitat enhancement projects, which the Gwent wildlife trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation following the inquiry, after which Welsh government ministers will decide on the project's approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics, following a report by Novaya Gazeta on 1 April, held a meeting on 3 April, condemning the publication for allegedly insulting their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The clerics issued a resolution calling for "retribution against the true instigators," which Novaya Gazeta interprets as a call for reprisals against journalists. The report, published on 1 April, revealed that over 100 individuals suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three reported killed. The Russian LGBT Network, in contact with the victims, confirmed these allegations, stating that detainees were subjected to torture. The Chechen authorities, led by Ramzan Kadyrov, a loyal ally of President Vladimir Putin, deny these claims, calling them "lies" and asserting that there are no gay people in Chechnya. The Mufti of Chechnya, Salah-haji Mezhiev, echoed the sentiment of retribution, stating that Allah will punish those who slandered the Chechen nation and clerics. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, defended the publication, asserting that they did not intend to insult the Chechen people and will continue investigating human rights abuses. The LGBT Network, which is assisting persecuted individuals, warns of potential ICC action if Russia does not prosecute the perpetrators.

Investing Solutions, a charity founded by Samir Patel in 2002, has been receiving significant housing benefit payments for housing single homeless men over 35 in London. The charity, Fresh Start Housing, established in 2010, identifies clients from local homeless charities. Both entities operate from the same south London storage unit. Investing Solutions earns substantial profits by placing multiple unrelated individuals in a single property and charging housing benefit for each person, leading to higher benefit payouts than the rent paid to landlords.

The charity claims to focus on reducing poverty and distress among ex-offenders and those facing accommodation challenges. However, critics argue that the arrangement is exploitative, with one former tenant, Nigel McCann, describing unsuitable properties with issues like lack of heating, hot water, and infestations. McCann also expressed concern about the profit motive, stating that the company seemed more interested in money than people.

Investing Solutions has received substantial funding from Wandsworth Council, totaling over £2.1 million over the past two years, with nearly half of this amount coming from the council. The council maintains a dedicated team to ensure safety, security, and affordability in the private rented sector.

Matt Downie from homeless charity Crisis condemned the practice, calling it a "new low" in housing benefit misuse. Samir Patel defended the charity, asserting that Fresh Start Housing is an independent entity with its own board of trustees, and the majority of properties are sourced from private sector landlords. He also expressed concern about the condition of one landlord's property.

Despite the controversy, Fresh Start Housing reported housing 788 homeless individuals since its inception and 222 in the past year, with 222 of these being re-housed tenants. The charity, however, declined to disclose the number of individuals housed through Investing Solutions. The Department for Communities and Local Government stated that local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers' money in the private sector housing sector.

In a recent friendly match, Team GB, led by coach Joe Prunty, secured a 71-60 victory over the Netherlands. Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon, both NBA players, contributed 14 and 13 points respectively. Despite a strong start, Team GB lost momentum in the final quarter, allowing the Netherlands to reclaim the lead. Prunty, preparing for Eurobasket qualifiers, emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity throughout the game. He acknowledged that his team lost some of their competitive edge in the latter stages. Gordon, who was not part of the London 2012 squad, made a significant impact, particularly in the third quarter with three consecutive three-pointers. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, dominated the fourth quarter, scoring the first 10 points to secure their win. Prunty expressed satisfaction with Gordon's performance, noting his crucial stretch in the third quarter. Team GB will now proceed with their Eurobasket qualifying campaign, starting with a game in Hungary midweek.

Conor McGregor, a former five-weight world champion, has submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for his upcoming boxing match against Floyd Mayweather Jr., hours before the deadline. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, stated they expected the request on Wednesday. The fight, scheduled for 16 August, will be debated by the NAC, considering the 154 lbs weight class requires 10oz gloves, a decision that could impact the punishment of punches due to less hand cushioning. Mayweather had previously posted on Instagram about using 8oz gloves, but McGregor's team sought clarification on the process for lighter gloves. NAC executive director Bob Bennett emphasized the commission's priority for fighter health and safety, stating that deviating from regulations at this weight difference would be a chairman and commissioners' decision.

McGregor, 29, will make his boxing debut in what could be the most lucrative fight in history. Despite criticism from prominent boxing figures, Bennett approved the fight based on McGregor's UFC rival Nate Diaz's sparring performance, McGregor's impressive chin, and his youth and height advantage over Mayweather. McGregor defeated Diaz three times in their August 2016 fight, avenging a submission loss earlier in the year.

Since the fight's sanctioning, Bennett has reviewed three videos of McGregor's progress, confirming his readiness. He advised McGregor's team to employ a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Hall of Fame official Joe Cortez, 73. Cortez, who oversaw an intense sparring session between McGregor and Paulie Malignaggi, left the camp after reacting negatively to images of him on the canvas during the session.

The passage narrates the historical significance of Fleet Street, once the epicenter of British journalism, where numerous national and provincial newspapers had their offices. It was established in 1702 with the Daily Courant, and at its peak, it housed nearly every major national paper and several provincial ones within a half-mile radius. Notable figures like Robin Esser, who spent 60 years in journalism, highlight its importance during the early days of television and before the advent of social media, when 85% of public information came through newspapers.

Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, both veteran journalists from the Sunday Post, worked in Fleet Street for 32 and 25 years respectively. They describe the street as a vibrant hub of journalists and printers, filled with bars and pubs, and a place where the atmosphere was lively and filled with camaraderie. Their memories echo the era of smoke-filled newsrooms, typewriters, and the absence of modern technology like computers and digital printing.

The decline of Fleet Street began in the late 1980s when media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, sparking a dispute with unions. This led to most national newspapers relocating to other parts of London, adopting new, cheaper printing technology. Consequently, the iconic Fleet Street buildings transformed into various commercial uses, such as supermarket headquarters and restaurants.

The passage concludes with the retirement of Sherriff and Smith, who are now freelance journalists and authors, respectively. Despite the end of their professional careers, they still find the historical significance of Fleet Street exciting and a part of their personal narrative in journalism.

J.K. Rowling, the renowned Harry Potter author, expressed her thoughts on the vastness of the world and the prevalence of decent individuals following a series of abusive comments on Twitter. She previously faced backlash for her £1m donation to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, which was criticized as crossing a personal line. In 2008, she had made a similar donation to the Labour party. Last year, Rowling encountered further criticism for her political views, being labeled a "traitor" by some SNP supporters. She defended her stance, stating she felt no obligation to silence such criticism to protect any political party's image. Despite this, she engaged with some SNP supporters who shared common political views with her. Rowling also humorously responded to a Twitter user suggesting her books should be burned, promising to bring marshmallows instead. The Scottish National Party (SNP), which she had previously criticized, won 56 out of 59 Scottish seats in the recent election, making it the third-largest party in the UK.

The University of Edinburgh's research, as detailed in the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, reveals that children from impoverished backgrounds are twice as likely to encounter police action for the same crime compared to their wealthier peers. Living in poverty also heightens the propensity for violence among both boys and girls, with poorer young people being approximately five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. The study, which has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998, found that a history of police involvement is the strongest predictor of young people not being in education, employment, or training by age 18.

Gender plays a significant role in predicting violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds being twice as likely to be involved in violent crime. These findings, published in the Scottish Justice Matters journal, indicate that poverty exacerbates the risk of both offending and victimization, even when other risk factors are considered.

Despite a reported decrease in overall crime rates in Scotland, recent studies suggest that the most chronically crime-ridden areas remain disproportionately poor, with high levels of chronic health problems and unemployment. The Scottish government, acknowledging these findings, asserts that Scotland is safer than ever, with 1,000 additional police officers on the streets and a 41-year low in recorded crime. However, they also highlight their ongoing efforts to address poverty and inequalities, including a £296 million investment to mitigate the impacts of UK welfare cuts.

In the early hours of Sunday, 25-year-old Mr Haugh was fatally stabbed in a laneway of the Marian estate in Kilkee. Robbie Walsh, 25, from Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and has been held in custody, with his next court appearance scheduled for the following week. Two other men initially arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge, and their cases are being forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

According to Det Sgt Padraig Frawley, Mr Walsh, along with two other individuals, entered the Marian Estate around 1:00 AM on Sunday, seeking Mr Haugh. A fight ensued, involving Mr Haugh and another man, during which Mr Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Garda arrived and found knives and a golf club at the scene. Mr Haugh was taken to Limerick University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead at 6:00 AM. Police recovered a blood-stained knife blade at the crime scene.

A judge acknowledged the heightened tension in the Kilkee area following the killing and ordered Mr Walsh to remain in custody until his next court date on 14 August.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a question about former UDR member Tom Elliott, suggesting he might disclose details of harassment and shootings during his tenure. This tweet, which was deleted within an hour, was prompted by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. The High Court heard that Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, has a clear MoD record. Elliott was alerted to the tweet by Travers and Foster. The court also learned that Flanagan's insurance firm, which covers MLAs at Stormont, declined to provide coverage for any compensation and costs in this case. Flanagan is contesting this decision in a separate legal action. Elliott, in response, expressed satisfaction with the outcome, stating that Flanagan admitted the tweet was untrue and wholly without foundation, and that he had been vindicated.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, has seen a significant boost in production due to increased demand for its branded sweater range, launched in January. The company, now managed by Benny Hartop since November, has expanded its weekly production from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters, primarily driven by strong sales of the new line and growing orders for private label customers. Hawick Knitwear caters to various international markets, including Europe (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain) and North America (USA, Canada, Mexico), as well as Japan. The firm's growth is attributed to the robust performance of both its private label and newly launched brand, with Hartop expressing optimism about the company's future, crediting the hard work of its staff for this success.

Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man from Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for causing serious injury by dangerous driving, specifically for hitting Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not stop for a red light, hitting Mrs. Blackburn as she was directing traffic. Despite his assertion of being blinded by the sun, the jury heard that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into his eyes. Mrs. Blackburn, a 20-year veteran lollipop lady and mother of three, is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, acknowledging Mrs. Blackburn's significant impact on the children and her family. The incident occurred when Mrs. Blackburn was on duty, escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road, with traffic in the opposite direction having stopped. The trial is ongoing.

This passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at preparing for potential threats from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, and anti-submarine warfare helicopters. The primary target is the German U-boat U33, but the focus is on the unseen Russian submarines, particularly the newly launched "quietest submarine in the world" by President Putin. These submarines, with around 60 in Russia's fleet, can remain undetected for months, posing a significant challenge to NATO's defenses.

The crew of the USS Vicksburg, led by Rear Admiral Brad Williamson, is tasked with locating and tracking these submarines, which appear as brief periscope sightings. The exercise also includes underwater unmanned vehicles or drones, Harpo and Groucho, for persistent surveillance, and a French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft for long-range scanning.

Britain, lacking its own maritime patrol aircraft since the retirement of the Nimrod, has to rely on NATO allies for aerial support. This situation is highlighted as a critical vulnerability, emphasizing the need for Britain to address this gap in its defense review. The exercise underscores the growing concern over Russia's increasing military strength and the need for collective defense among NATO members.

The passage describes a severe humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, where ethnic violence has led to a mass exodus of over 340,000 people, making it the country with the highest number of refugees globally in 2016. The conflict, initiated by a dispute between President Salva Kiir (Dinka) and former Vice-President Riek Machar (Nuer), escalated in July, targeting Equatorians as well. The violence has resulted in widespread killing, rape, and civilian targeting along ethnic lines. Nelson Ladu Thomas and Otima Amos, two refugees, share their harrowing experiences of fleeing their homes in Yei and other parts of South Sudan, highlighting the brutal realities of the conflict.

Uganda, a neighboring country, has been accommodating these refugees, providing them with land, tarpaulins, and support to start farming. Despite Uganda's generosity, the influx has strained its resources, particularly in supplying water to the refugees. The UNHCR's senior emergency coordinator, Nasir Abel Fernandes, emphasizes the urgent need for international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the violence, describing it as a "massacre of civilians from both sides."

The passage also touches on the resilience of the refugees, particularly children, who continue to attend school and engage in cultural activities, despite their traumatic experiences. Their performances, like Patricia Mercy's poem, reflect their strength and determination to maintain a sense of normalcy amidst the chaos.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer from Norwich and Peterborough, will compete in the English super-middleweight championship against Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November. He turned professional in 2013, following his retirement from football two years prior. With a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights, McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie. His training is managed by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a three-time world champion.

The coalition government has allocated £330m for new NHS facilities in England, with Bridgwater Community Hospital being one of the beneficiaries. This hospital, built in 1813, is being upgraded to a modern facility with 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray services, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital is described as outdated and in need of significant repairs, with Matron Sue Taylor emphasizing the impact of the environment on patient recovery. In the past five years, three out of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and similar progress is being made with the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. Dr. Donal Hynes, a Bridgwater GP, highlights the positive impact this new hospital will have on his patient care. The new hospital is planned to be constructed on land at Bowers Lane, subject to planning permission, with the aim of completion by autumn 2014.

A fatal shooting incident occurred on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield's city centre, around 1:35 PM GMT. The victim, a man, was found with a gunshot wound to his chest outside a property. He was a resident of the area and was reportedly in or near his black Mercedes car when he was shot. Armed police secured the scene, and the man was rushed to Northern General Hospital but succumbed to his injuries. Neighbours stated that the man was part of a family who were gathering for a celebration when the attack happened. The community quickly responded, with relatives attempting to assist him after hearing the shot. This incident is one of several shootings in Sheffield recently, with previous ones happening in the city's north, not in the Upperthorpe area. Notably, a 25-year-old man was seriously injured in Shiregreen, and an elderly couple experienced a mistaken identity shooting in Southey Green, while two houses in High Green were targeted in separate incidents in January.

The passage discusses three significant cyber warfare groups involved in the Ukraine conflict: Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their DDoS attacks, hacking Russian interior ministry servers, and disrupting separatist funding by targeting accounts in electronic payment systems. They've also infiltrated public CCTV systems and electronic billboards in eastern Ukraine and Crimea. Dokukin recently claimed to have printed pro-Ukrainian messages and insults against Russian President Vladimir Putin using network printers.

Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and accuses Kiev of orchestrating a "genocide" at America's behest. They've hacked Ukrainian government websites, claimed to retrieve confidential documents from a US official's device, and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Cyber Berkut also allegedly hacked electronic billboards in Kiev to brand Ukrainian officials as "war criminals" and published a supposed Facebook conversation implicating Ukrainian forces in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17.

Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, is a Russian activist group that gained notoriety for publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin. They focus on Russia's domestic affairs but have also covered Ukraine. Their activities include publishing a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine and leaking emails between former Russian FSB colonel Igor Girkin, a key rebel commander. Access to their website is currently blocked in Russia.

In a poignant farewell ceremony, Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, shed tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond, former first minister, bid adieu to the Scottish Parliament. Both McNeil and Salmond, along with Marwick, are among those resigning ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's unity and diversity, asserting that the country and parliament are on a shared journey towards greater governance responsibility. He acknowledged the Scotland Bill's transfer of powers but criticized it for not fulfilling pre-referendum pledges. Salmond also joked about the competition from the Cheltenham racecourse and wished all election candidates good luck, albeit with varying enthusiasm.

Duncan McNeil, in his emotional final speech, highlighted the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition in the Scottish Parliament, drawing parallels with Westminster's committee system. He expressed regret at having to learn from Westminster's practices, given his previous involvement in its reform. Annabel Goldie, another departing MSP, concluded her speech with a light-hearted remark about her future interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is initiating a review to assess the quality of life and care provided to older individuals residing in residential care across Wales. She aims to gather firsthand accounts from pensioners and their supporters to understand both the positive impacts of high-quality care and the negative effects of poor care. This review will encompass various aspects, including physical and psychological health, social connections, and the care home environment. Rochira intends to use this evidence to form recommendations for care providers and public bodies, emphasizing the need for improved services. She has already conducted extensive travels across Wales to meet with residents and observed the positive influence of excellent care. However, she has also received numerous complaints about inconsistent care quality, which she deems unacceptable. The Care Forum Wales, while supporting the review's objectives, expresses disappointment that a care provider expert is not part of the main advisory panel, arguing this overlooks the potential for sector collaboration and comprehensive input.

Harbro Group, headquartered in Aberdeenshire's Turriff, reported a £800,000 rise in pre-tax profit to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m decrease in turnover, bringing it to just over £100m. The company's international sales expanded in Europe and new global markets. Harbro specializes in manufacturing and supplying feeds for various livestock sectors, including beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry. Additionally, it operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, offering farming and rural community products like fireside supplies and country clothing. The company acknowledged the unpredictability of the agricultural sector's future, citing challenging times over the past 18 months, but expressed confidence in the industry's resilience. The impact of Brexit remains uncertain, but Harbro's board believes the group will be well-prepared for any potential business challenges.

A 70-year-old man's body was discovered at a residence in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was hospitalized. The police are treating the death as a murder and are actively seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, for questioning. McLoughlin is described as a white man, approximately 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair, and an average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked shirt. The police are urging the public to refrain from approaching him and are encouraging anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols are being conducted in the area to ensure resident reassurance.

David Lipton, the second-in-command at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), warned of a weakening global economy during a speech at the National Association for Business Economics in Washington. He highlighted that the IMF's recent assessment indicates a downward trend, placing the global economy at a critical stage. This warning follows China's underperformance in trade, with exports declining by 25% compared to the previous year. The IMF anticipates a revision of its current global growth forecast from 3.4% to a lower figure when it updates its predictions in April. This deteriorating economic scenario poses significant challenges for businesses and industries that rely on China's growth prospects.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with the newly launched chain ferry, which has encountered problems since its launch on May 14, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspensions due to training issues. The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until July 2 to gather feedback and acknowledge the difficulties. The council has commissioned an auditor to review the project. Local businesses, particularly shopkeeper Angie Booth, have suffered significant losses due to the ferry's suspension, with her store bearing almost six months of trade loss. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the teething problems as expected in a prototype, noting that electrical issues have been resolved. He also mentioned that the council has authorized the production of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage and addressed seamanship-related groundings. Compensation for local businesses was proposed, but not yet confirmed.

A fatal car accident occurred on the southbound carriageway, close to the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. The incident involved multiple vehicles. Tragically, a 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was subsequently arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was shut down between Thursley and Liphook, remaining closed until early evening as police conducted their investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has been criticized for its job advertisements that emphasize physical attributes, particularly for a personal assistant role requiring a "classic look" and specific hair and bust size. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners, including the Fawcett Society, condemned these ads as demeaning and potentially unlawful, citing violations of the 2010 Equality Act. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating that looks are crucial for representing clients and making first impressions. However, employment lawyer James Lynas asserts that such advertisements could be considered discriminatory, especially if they imply a preference for younger, attractive individuals over older or less conventionally attractive candidates. The agency's clients include prestigious brands like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Coca-Cola, and they also cater to specific client preferences, such as an Indian businessman's desire for a blonde, blue-eyed, Greek woman. Despite the controversy, Matching Models continues to operate, emphasizing the importance of professional skills alongside physical attributes in their hiring process.

A shooting incident took place at a hostel linked to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, India. The perpetrator, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, allegedly entered the room of 18-year-old Gautami and shot her in the head with a pistol on Tuesday evening. He also injured another student, Sirisha, who is reportedly recovering. Mahesh was apprehended on Wednesday following a manhunt. This event is unusual in India, where gun crimes at educational institutions are rare. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear. India maintains strict firearm control laws, yet many disputes are resolved through firearm settlements. A notable historical incident occurred in 2007 when a 14-year-old student was fatally shot by fellow students at a school campus near Delhi.

Glaad, an advocacy group, conducted a study from June 2016 to May 2017, analyzing scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. The analysis revealed 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with a significant increase in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, the report highlighted a concerning trend: over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters met violent ends, including Poussey Washington from Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith from Wentworth. The study also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, primarily due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, expressed optimism about the progress made but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided to step down ahead of a local party meeting, where his re-election was anticipated to be challenged. The decision comes amidst a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities concerning a £10.25m loan from Northampton Borough Council to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment and land development. The loan, which Mackintosh was involved in as leader, is now missing, and the football stand remains unfinished. Despite his initial intention to contest re-election, Mackintosh stated that it is time for his constituents to have a new representative. His party's local executive council had previously indicated they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer from Balch Springs, Dallas suburb, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards, who was in a car leaving a party where underage drinking was reported. The incident occurred in April, and Oliver was dismissed shortly after for policy violations. Initially, police claimed the car reversed towards them, but footage contradicted this, showing it driving away. Oliver is charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for the other teenagers in the car. He faces 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted, marking the first police officer murder conviction in Dallas county since 1973. The trial has not been scheduled yet, and Oliver remains free on bail. The Edwards family's lawyer, Lee Merritt, expressed cautious optimism, acknowledging the murder indictment but noting the rarity of such convictions in Texas.

The president-elect, in response to queries about Mrs. Trump and Barron moving to Washington after Barron finishes school, has stated they will relocate "very soon." However, this has sparked mixed reactions on social media, with some criticizing the decision, particularly due to concerns about Barron's schooling. Others have supported Mrs. Trump, citing her focus on Barron's well-being. Historically, only two First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Mrs. Trump's decision is not unprecedented, as other First Ladies, like Dolley Madison and Chelsea Clinton, also sent their children to school before moving into the White House. The role of the First Lady, traditionally ceremonial, has seen varying levels of public engagement. Some, like Eleanor Roosevelt and Michelle Obama, have been more visible, while others, like Nancy Reagan, maintained a more private focus. Mrs. Trump has hinted at prioritizing cyber-bullying initiatives, suggesting she may not fully embrace the traditional full-time public role. The Obamas, for instance, managed to keep their daughters, Malia and Sasha, in the same school during their fathers' presidencies, setting an example for how families can adapt to living in the White House.

A 72-year-old man passed away on 27 October in Inverness. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, has been tasked by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with this investigation, and a report detailing the commissioner's findings will be presented to COPFS subsequently.

A yellow wind warning was issued, predicting gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) in the western areas, especially near mountains, due to an unusual easterly wind direction. This is expected to cause significant travel disruptions on roads and at sea. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight, strong winds caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, leading to the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday to facilitate cleanup operations.

In the initial game, the Giants, led by player-coach Derrick Walser, started with a short-handed goal. However, Jeff Dimmen's equalizer for the Panthers ensued. Mike Forney's powerplay goal in the second period extended the Giants' lead to 2-1, followed by Andy Bohmback's equalizer. Mike Radja then scored from a challenging angle, and James Desmarais added another goal, making the score 4-2. Nottingham's David Ling managed to score a consolation goal. The teams will face off again the following Saturday, as part of a double-header, with Nottingham currently leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27, and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton, the world champion, started from the back of the grid due to a broken front wing on lap one. He had to make five pit stops, suffering from a 36-point deficit in the championship. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel secured second place, despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen managed to recover to fifth, passing Hamilton in the final stages. The race was marked by numerous incidents, including collisions on the first lap, leading to the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton's car was significantly damaged in the initial collisions, affecting its aerodynamic performance. Vettel and Raikkonen used soft tyres in the final stint, giving Raikkonen an advantage over Hamiland. Mercedes opted for medium tyres, which hindered Hamilton's progress. The race was dominated by Mercedes' Nico Rosberg, who took the lead after a first-corner collision and maintained his position, while Hamilton struggled to recover ground. Hamilton faces a challenging task to close the 36-point gap to teammate Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races of the season, as no driver who won the first three races has ever gone on to claim the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly declared his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to spark a discussion on a topic that has been largely overlooked in German football. His announcement was met with widespread support from fellow players, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as from key figures in German football administration, such as former German FA president Theo Zwanziger and current Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball. They praised Hitzlsperger's courage and viewed his decision as a significant stride in combating homophobia in the sport. The announcement is seen as a pivotal moment in Germany, where homophobia has been a persistent issue, with the last openly gay German footballer being Marcus Urban in 2007. Current German captain Philipp Lahm's past stance against openly gay footballers has been criticized, and his predecessor, Volker Beck, hopes Hitzlsperger's move will inspire more players to follow suit. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman also endorsed Hitzlsperger's decision, emphasizing that footballers should be judged based on their behavior, not their sexual orientation. Zwanziger expressed optimism that Hitzlsperger's announcement could lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, contributing significantly to Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. His contract is set to expire at the end of the season, and he is actively seeking a new deal to continue his role in the top flight. Brighton's victory over Wigan secured their promotion, with a four-point lead over second-placed Newcastle. Sidwell, who previously played in the Premier League with teams like Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, made 19 appearances on loan for Brighton in 2015-16 before signing a one-year contract with the club in June 2016. He expressed his desire to play at the Premier League level again and believes he has delivered a better impact than anticipated, given the number of games he has played. If a new contract offer materializes, he aims to finalize it before the summer.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, who scored from a chip into the area. Colchester equalized from a corner in the 17th minute, with Kurtis Guthrie heading in from close range. Despite Blackpool's chances to extend their lead, including a missed opportunity by Tom Aldred in the 75th minute, and Colchester's best chance blocked by Blackpool's Jim McAlister, the game remained tied. Colchester's George Elokobi and Kurtis Guthrie had close-range efforts saved by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with Colchester finishing with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a violent tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.
