A 29-year-old player, previously with Charlton, Bradford, Preston, and Colchester, made 37 appearances for the latter last season as they were relegated from League One. He is expected to make his debut for Colchester United in their EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa, a Championship side. Colchester began their new season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington on Saturday. For the most recent football transfer news, refer to the dedicated page.

In response to the tragic murder of PC Keith Palmer in March, the UK Police Memorial Trust initiated a fundraising campaign for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The proposed memorial, costing approximately £4m, aims to honor over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasized the need for a fitting tribute that recognizes the significant role of policing in society and acknowledges the courage and sacrifice of fallen officers. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, serving as personal memorials for the families of deceased officers. The government, led by Home Secretary Amber Rudd, pledged £1m towards the project, with the remaining funds expected to be raised. The memorial is anticipated to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United, currently 15 points ahead at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left, secured a 1-0 victory over Sunderland. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on the upcoming matches, particularly the derby against Manchester City, where they hold a 15-point lead. United has demonstrated exceptional form, winning 50 out of 54 possible points in their last 18 league games. They aim to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record from 2005. Ferguson acknowledged injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, but expressed satisfaction with how the team managed these setbacks. Changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea, with Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley likely to be substituted due to fatigue from recent international duty. Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez are expected to be available, while Rio Ferdinand will return to the lineup. Ferguson praised his team's defensive resilience and courage, noting that Sunderland made the match challenging, but United's performance in the first half deserved the win.

In response to criticism over Google's tax practices, specifically its use of Ireland as a tax haven to minimize UK payments, Google's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, asserted that the company adheres to all legal requirements for tax payments in the UK. Between 2006 and 2011, Google paid approximately £10m in UK corporate taxes. Mr. Schmidt emphasized that tax obligations are non-negotiable and should be met according to the law, stating that any changes in tax laws should be a political decision for the UK government.

Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed the creation of a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of large corporations, enabling the committee to hear confidential evidence from these companies. This move aims to prevent tax evasion through confidentiality rules.

The European Union has also taken action, agreeing to implement an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities" to monitor tax avoidance. Google, along with other multinationals, has been criticized for structuring their tax affairs to minimize UK payments.

Mr. Schmidt has advocated for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are taken, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for international tax reform and a debate on setting tax rules, arguing that politicians, not companies, should determine these rules.

NHS Improvement, the regulatory body, has set a target to decrease the agency staff expenditure by £1bn by the end of the current financial year, from the £3.6bn spent last year. A cap was implemented in October, which has already saved £600m, limiting hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services from paying more than 55% above normal shift rates for all staff, except senior managers. The aim is to decrease the overall cost of agency staff and reduce the NHS's reliance on them, as agency staff are more expensive due to additional agency fees and employers' costs. Despite progress, NHS trusts are still 10% behind their targets, and the agency bill is falling but not necessarily other pay components. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" of trusts based on agency spending and details of the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust to address concerns about excessive payments. The regulator has uncovered instances of hospitals being quoted significantly higher rates for doctors, such as £130 an hour for a surgeon and £70 for a junior doctor, which exceed the cap rates. NHS Improvement CEO, Jim Mackey, emphasized the urgent need for further reductions, stating that the NHS lacks the financial resources to sustain such high agency staff costs.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger's prosperity, now serves as a symbol of the Republic of Ireland's economic downturn following the crash. Despite a 30% decline in business over the past few years, local traders like Matt O'Brien, who owns a family-owned men's clothing shop, are optimistic about a potential turnaround. They've diversified their offerings, including children's wear and dress-hire services, to attract more customers.

The local Fianna Fáil party criticizes the Fine Gael-Labour coalition's handling of the midlands, particularly the allocation of resources. They argue that the half-a-billion euro investment in water meters should be directed towards broadband improvement, as the Industrial Development Authority (IDA) has not successfully attracted foreign direct investment to Longford for over four years.

In contrast, the government highlights recent positive developments, such as the announcement of Center Parcs' plans to create 1,000 jobs in Ballymahon with a 200m euro investment. The proposed tourism development, set to open in 2019, is expected to leverage the area's natural beauty and infrastructure. However, the project still requires planning permission.

Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon expresses confidence in the venture's success, emphasizing the region's unique attractions. Meanwhile, traders like Matt O'Brien advocate for additional measures to stimulate local business, such as free street parking, to further encourage footfall. Overall, while there are signs of economic recovery in Longford, traders and the opposition party agree that more needs to be done to support local businesses and attract investment.

The Indian Premier League (IPL) competition concludes on 29 May at the same stadium, featuring eight teams. Each team plays every other team twice, with the top four teams advancing to the play-offs. The tournament's fixtures and results are available on BBC Sport. Notable players include Warner (294 runs, 12 most sixes), Kohli (267 runs, 8 most sixes), De Villiers (249 runs, 12 most sixes), and De Kock (108 highest score). McClenaghan (9 wickets), Kumar (8 wickets), and Rahman (7 wickets) lead in dismissals. Four former England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—participate in the tournament, representing Sunrisers Hyderabad, Mumbai Indians, Delhi Daredevils, and Rising Pune Supergiants, respectively. The detailed schedule of matches is provided from 25 April to 29 May, with the play-offs and final on the specified dates.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a significant increase of 200 million plastic carrier bags since 2013, primarily due to their non-recyclable nature and frequent disposal after single use. These bags frequently end up in landfills and water bodies, causing substantial environmental harm. To address this, a 5p charge for plastic bags will be implemented in England starting from October, aiming to incentivize reusing existing bags. This initiative, inspired by successful measures in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, has shown a decline in bag usage in those regions. Environmental advocates anticipate this charge will similarly reduce plastic bag waste in England, thereby mitigating environmental impact.

On Friday, December 23, a significant portion of a school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, Caernarfon, Gwynedd, amidst severe wind warnings across Wales. This incident coincided with widespread power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and adverse weather conditions. The highest wind gusts were recorded on Anglesey's Mona. Irish Ferries suspended six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to unfavorable sea conditions. Arriva Trains Wales implemented speed restrictions and potential delays for services between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to anticipated high winds. The National Trust also closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds subsided by evening, lifting restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge. However, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, originally scheduled for Saturday, December 24, to Tuesday, December 27. Travelers should be aware of these disruptions for their journeys.

The individual, who recently expressed his excitement about a new project, is set to collaborate with his Creed director, Ryan Coogler, for an upcoming film. He is eager to bring a fresh perspective to the role, though specifics remain undisclosed. Additionally, he is thrilled to work with Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o, known for her role in 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently portraying Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. This film is expected to be released in February 2018, following the success of Black Panther in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

The passage discusses the restoration project of Alexandra Palace, a historic venue established in 1875. The primary focus is to revive the theatre, which was initially intended for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios, situated at the eastern end of the palace, will also undergo repairs and refurbishment. The aim is to reopen the theatre in 2018, making it a new cultural hub. This initiative is part of a broader east wing restoration project, transforming Alexandra Palace into a vibrant cultural destination. The glazed east court will be transformed into a public space and exhibition area. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust is pledging the remaining £1m by summer 2017. Despite decades of inactivity, the theatre retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, reflecting its historical purpose of hosting opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, who made his senior debut in 2009, has earned 61 caps for England. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only featured for three minutes during Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player (46 caps), made his first appearance in 2004. His sole international goal was scored in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He expressed well-wishes for Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters in a statement following a decision.

Marcy Smith and her son David were awakened by a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, which they managed to escape from, but their dog and cats perished. The fire, ignited by rubbish David had burned in the wood stove, spread rapidly, consuming the entire kitchen. Despite the fire alarm not activating, David, who was on a FaceTime call with his father, was the only one awake and alerted the family. The community has shown significant support, providing clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Marcy Smith attributes her and her daughter's survival to David's quick action, emphasizing his heroism and expressing pride in his bravery.

The energy drinks company, with Sullivan and Gold as majority owners, previously acquired West Ham for £105m in 2010, now holding over 85% of the club's shares. Following the club's relocation to London Stadium in August, West Ham has been approached by potential takeovers from Qatari and Chinese entities. Sullivan previously mentioned the possibility of selling a minority stake to alleviate debts, but he and Gold have expressed their intention to pass on the ownership to their descendants.

The 22 Jump Street star Jillian Bell made a humorous comment about the event not being the Oscars on the red carpet in Los Angeles. The ceremony, which served as an unofficial promotional platform for summer blockbusters, featured fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance, with Zac Efron winning the latter again. The main event was the announcement of the best movie award, won by The Fault in Our Stars. Shailene Woodley, the film's star, also received accolades for best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. She dedicated her awards to John Green, the author of the book adaptation. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for his role in American Sniper, while Channing Tatum was honored for best comedic performance in 22 Jump Street. Meryl Streep received the best villain award for her role in Into the Woods. Other notable winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart, despite size-related jokes, accepted the comedic genius award with his children. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award from his Avengers co-stars, who presented him with the award. The show also showcased clips from upcoming films like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned to St Mirren from Aberdeen in July. Since joining, he has scored five goals in the current season. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four goals in 89 appearances for the team. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised Smith as a "brilliant acquisition," highlighting his maturity and potential to strengthen their attacking lineup. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will face Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council has announced that the current weather conditions are suitable for its Jetpatcher machines to address the potholes. The council plans to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra personnel will be deployed to repair damaged drainage systems due to heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors, including Steve Innes, working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). The exposure occurred during a routine shutdown operation while removing pipework. The workers, who were not wearing adequate personal protective equipment (PPE), were informed about the contamination two-thirds through the task. EnQuest and Wood Group have since acknowledged the incident, with EnQuest confirming the exposure and Wood Group emphasizing their commitment to employee safety. Both companies have implemented additional precautionary measures to prevent future incidents. However, the workers, including Innes, express concerns about long-term health risks and the companies' duty of care, as they were initially assured the exposure might not cause long-term harm. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has not investigated the incident due to it not meeting the reportable threshold under the RIDDOR system. Unite, the union, criticizes the handling of the situation, advocating for transparency and openness to improve offshore working conditions.

In 2007, the Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past. Later, it was revealed that the dealer, Aaron Freedman, had admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this particular piece. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, southern India. Following allegations of trafficking antiquities in a 2012 court case, ACM decided to return the sculpture after consultations with Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI requested the return of the sculpture in May, and ACM acknowledged the confession of Freedman regarding his involvement in dealing with looted Indian antiquities. Although 29 other items bought from Art of the Past are not suspected of being stolen, ACM plans to seek legal compensation for the alleged fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake occurred 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, on the 15th of an unspecified month. This tremor was felt as far as Milan and Florence, causing minor damage and disruption, including downed phone lines and power cuts in the Garfagnana area. No immediate reports of injuries or significant damage were made. Italy, known for its seismic activity, has experienced a series of earthquakes, including one in 2009 that resulted in nearly 300 deaths in L'Aquila. The latest quake, described as medium-strong and shallow, was felt in various cities like Milan, Bologna, Modena, and Lucca, causing people to evacuate schools in the affected region. The area has a history of false reassurances from authorities, as six scientists and an ex-official were convicted in 2012 for providing misleading information about the 2009 quake, leading to fatalities.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, South Yorkshire, expressed his delight after witnessing the successful growth of a fruit on a plant, despite initial doubts about the region's climate. The fruit is still attached to the plant and is not yet ripe for consumption.

Rockstar Games has postponed the release of their open-world adventure game, GTA V, from 27 January to 24 March. The delay is due to additional testing and refinement to ensure the game meets their high standards. Rockstar assured fans that these extra weeks will enhance the overall quality of the game. In a positive note, they announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, which is expected to feature superior visuals. Screenshots show Los Santos and Blaine County in 1080p at 60fps, with up to 4K resolution and triple monitor support. Meanwhile, the minimum PC specifications for running GTA V have been revealed. The game, which broke records by generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its initial release on 17 September 2013, is anticipated to be even more impressive upon its March release.

The 76-year-old artist, who has been shortlisted for the John Moores Painting Prize three times before, won the £25,000 prize for his painting 'Squint (19)' at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting, depicting a leper squint, a medieval architectural feature, was described as "quite extraordinary" by judge Ansel Krut. Simpson, who has been working on a series of similar paintings, entered 'Squint (19)' due to its relatively small size and his familiarity with the subject. The prize money will be used for art materials, particularly high-quality paints. Krut likened the painting to a "tone poem," praising its subtlety and the profound sympathy it evokes. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with notable past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, the current patron, previously won the junior title in 1961.

According to the report from Yeni Safak, both Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit offices were targeted by four masked assailants in a coordinated attack on Thursday morning. The Yeni Safak building was directly assaulted, with gunfire causing damage to its windows and leaving spent bullet casings. The Yeni Akit offices, located 20km away, also experienced similar incidents. Firefighters promptly controlled the blaze, and police have cordoned off the areas around both buildings. No casualties were reported. The papers, which support the ruling AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, have not been linked to any group claiming responsibility for the attacks. This incident echoes a previous event in September, where pro-government protesters assaulted the Hurriyet offices, accusing the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player, previously on loan at Crawley from Stags, is set to join the team permanently on a free transfer, starting from 1st January. He had a successful half-season loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 matches. This move marks Marcus Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, whose contract ends in the summer, has been rumored for the England national team manager position, which currently holds with Gareth Southgate. Southgate, 46, has recently led England to a 2-0 win against Malta and a 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Wenger praised Southgate's growing experience and observational skills, emphasizing that the FA will evaluate his performance in upcoming matches, including a World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly against Spain. Wenger, 66, maintains focus on his current role, stating that competency is the primary factor in considering candidates, not just reputation. He also mentioned that Arsenal will offer a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, as he believes Bellerin's long-term future lies with the club. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, is expected to miss "one or two" more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

According to the passage, a local man employed at Fruehauf, situated on Houghton Road, is suspected to have fallen from a cherry picker around 1:45 PM GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, are leading the investigation. The company, Fruehauf, is fully cooperating with the inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink. The RMT union had alleged that some crew members were earning less than £4 an hour. The charter change will revert the services back to Serco Northlink, starting next month. Seatruck, the current operator, had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the non-UK resident crew. Despite Serco Northlink's repeated offers to cover the pay gap and backdate it, Seatruck refused. Minister Yousaf confirmed that the new arrangements, subject to finalizing financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage, effectively ending the long-standing issue. Serco Northlink secured a six-year, £243m contract in 2012 to operate three ferries and two cargo boats on the heavily subsidized Northern Isles route.

Ken Dickie, aged 64, passed away in hospital on 14 May, six days following an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, from Apple Close, admitted to intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother. Mitchell, visibly shaken, pleaded guilty to common assault and attempted to pervert the course of justice. The incident occurred on 7 May, when Mitchell, his mother Samantha, and Dickie were at the park bar, where they had been drinking. A confrontation ensued, leading to Mitchell trying to separate the two men, causing what he described as a "tragic accident." Initially, the trio claimed Dickie had pushed Samantha, who pushed him back, but later, Mitchell stated he had attempted to break up the fight. Both Mitchell and his mother were found guilty and will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter, passed away in London at 66 due to cancer, according to Warner/Chappell music publishing. Known for his significant contributions to Michael Jackson's discography, Temperton wrote three songs for the groundbreaking album "Off The Wall" and three more for "Thriller," including the iconic title track. His work on these albums helped "Thriller" become the best-selling album of all time in the US, with 32 million copies sold. Temperton's other notable hits include "Boogie Nights" for Heatwave and "Baby Be Mine" for Jackson. He was also recognized with a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his soundtrack contributions to "The Color Purple." Born in Cleethorpes, his songwriting roots were influenced by his father's radio transistor, which he would listen to as a child. Despite his success, Temperton maintained a low profile, earning him the nickname "The Invisible Man." His talent was widely acknowledged by fellow musicians, including Nile Rodgers, Chic guitarist, and Michael Jackson's sister, LaToya. Following his private funeral, tributes poured in from music industry figures like Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and BBC radio presenter Gilles Peterson, who highlighted his immense impact on music.

Swansea University researchers, Dr. Neil Loader and Alayne Street-Perrott, along with teams from Exeter, Reading, and SÃ£o Paulo universities and Brazil's BelÃ©m, have unearthed ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, dating back approximately 2,000 years. These discoveries encompass over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs," which are not believed to be villages or defensive structures due to the scarcity of artifacts and their non-defensive layout. Instead, they are thought to have served as sporadic ritual gathering places, akin to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids.

Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples, including phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon stable isotopes, revealed that these geoglyphs were likely constructed amidst taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy. This finding challenges the notion of pristine Amazonian forests before European arrival, suggesting instead a long history of human-induced environmental transformation. The research indicates that ancient inhabitants concentrated on economically valuable trees like palms, creating a form of "prehistoric supermarket" for forest products. The team posits that some of Acre's current forest biodiversity may still hold traces of these ancient agroforestry practices.

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th globally, secured a 6-4, 6-4 victory over world number 29 Bobby Querrey in just 53 minutes, advancing to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, expressed feeling fatigued and unusually quiet during the match. He attributed this to the physical exhaustion from his recent success in Japan and the travel demands of playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, located near Shanghai. Kyrgios mentioned that the long journey and poor sleep conditions had impacted his performance. This isn't the first time Kyrgios has faced disciplinary action; he was fined $1,500 at the Shanghai Masters last year for a profanity-laced rant, calling the tournament a "circus".

The passage discusses the potential benefits of expanding the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination program in Wales to include boys, in addition to girls aged 12 and 13. HPV is a sexually transmitted virus that can lead to cervical cancer in women. Currently, the vaccine is administered to girls to prevent cervical cancer. Charities like Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team are advocating for the inclusion of boys due to the rising number of head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger individuals. Dr. Mererid Evans, a consultant oncologist, noted that these cancers are increasingly affecting non-smoking men in their 50s. Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care emphasized the global significance of HPV in causing cancer and urged the Welsh government to take a proactive stance in addressing this public health issue. In 2008, an HPV vaccination program was initiated in Welsh schools, with 85% of girls vaccinated. The Welsh government, however, is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions regarding potential changes to the program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student at West Calder High School, was battling a rare form of blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. Despite his diagnosis in August, Jak maintained a positive attitude, documenting his journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey. His posts, shared with support from his mother Allison, sister Aimie, and girlfriend Hannah Boyd, garnered over 28,000 likes, showcasing his love for Rangers FC and interactions with former and current players.

On Saturday, Jak attended his school prom for 10 minutes before leaving due to feeling unwell. He was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. The event was organized to honor him, and his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity.

In January, Jak's cancer spread throughout his body, and doctors decided not to pursue further treatment. He expressed gratitude to medical staff and promised to fight the pain. His family then launched a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research following his diagnosis.

Jak's final days were filled with personal moments, including visits to the Kelpies, a romantic dinner with his girlfriend, a party attended by former Rangers stars Neil Alexander and Nacho Novo, and rides in a supercar and on a quad bike. A special football match is planned for Sunday at Livingston FC's Energy Assets Arena to raise additional funds for charity.

In a match played in Port-Gentil, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda, with the winning goal scored by substitute Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute. The goal came after Mohamed Salah set up El Said, who capitalized on a defensive error by Uganda. Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside in the 52nd minute. Egypt's goalkeeper, Essam El Hadary, made crucial saves, including one from Salah in the first half. Uganda's Faruku Miya was offside when he scored, and they failed to register a shot on target despite creating chances. This win puts Egypt in a position to face Ghana in the quarter-finals, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament for the first time since 1978. Ghana has already secured their spot in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali.

Lancashire County Council has identified the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, with Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus owned by Newcastle College, as potential sites for a new railway station. This decision is based on a comparative study conducted by Network Rail, which deemed these locations suitable. The preferred site, Glenburn Sports College, is expected to offer two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, facilitated by a partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. County Councillor John Fillis, responsible for highways and transport, views this as a significant advancement, noting the site's ample space for future expansion and excellent highway connectivity to the town and surrounding areas. Skelmersdale, designated as a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest of England without its own railway station. The council plans to initiate the acquisition process for the chosen land.

During a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, law enforcement discovered a sophisticated indoor cultivation setup, commonly referred to as a "grow house". A man in his late 40s was apprehended at the location.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman of Kurdish descent was discovered on a pavement late Sunday with severe injuries, having been dragged by her neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was subsequently airlifted to a specialized clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, surrendered to authorities. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive behind the attack remains unclear. Police have secured the crime scene and are seeking witnesses to aid their investigation.

The research, conducted by Cass Business School, the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, and based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, reveals that women are equally likely as men to request a pay rise. However, men are 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they ask for it. This study debunks the "reticent female" theory, which suggests women avoid asking for higher salaries due to fear of upsetting their bosses or adhering to gender stereotypes. The researchers controlled for factors like employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. Professor Andrew Oswald from the University of Warwick, a co-author, expressed surprise at these findings, suggesting that the discrepancy might indicate a degree of discrimination against women. The study also noted that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises equally, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behavior among younger women.

Oxford City Council has been actively seeking a new burial site for many years, conducting ground investigations on potential locations, but has found none suitable within the city. Currently, two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, remain as options, expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021 respectively. The council is not giving up on finding a new site, acknowledging that suitable land for burials is scarce due to factors like size constraints, poor ground conditions, high water tables, and covenants restricting use. Post-cemetery saturation, the council plans to explore reopening family plots, utilizing reserved plots, and interring ashes as the only remaining options. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, HebCelt, taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will introduce an augmented reality app for visitors. This app will enable users to access online content, including videos and band interviews, by scanning items like signs and posters at the festival site. The festival lineup includes renowned acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan emphasized that this augmented reality feature aims to enhance the festival experience for attendees and provide global audiences with an immersive, interactive way to engage with the event, offering real-time updates on festival happenings, ticket purchases, and a taste of the unique Celtic atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who had previously won prestigious races like the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite showing no signs of post-race ataxia on the day of his death, Many Clouds had previously exhibited symptoms of overheating and wobbling on his feet. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, stating it was a rare occurrence, even in horses without underlying health issues. Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, emphasized the sport's commitment to understanding and preventing such incidents. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described Many Clouds as "the horse of a lifetime," and the horse's history included successful treatments for overheating following his Grand National victory. However, the report concluded that Many Clouds' death was due to this uncommon haemorrhage, not his previous overheating condition.

Davina, a 34-year-old woman, is accused of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in the autumn of 2004. Davina, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer. The incident occurred while two others were asleep. The victim, who had consumed alcohol, recalled the assault, shouting and swearing at Davina to stop. Davina, then known as David Ayrton, changed her name in 2012. She will be sentenced on 4 March, with Judge Ian Pearson remanding her into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester due to concerns about her risk of self-harm and failure to attend court. The court also heard that Davina disclosed the rape to a care home worker in 2014.

In a tennis event in Rio, Serbs Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares defeated Djokovic and his partner 6-4, 6-4. This loss occurred a day following Djokovic's unexpected singles defeat at Wimbledon to Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world number one and a 12-time Grand Slam winner, had previously lost to American Sam Querrey at Wimbledon in July. Despite this setback, Djokovic managed to secure his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics. To stay updated on such sports news, one can subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter.

Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, will feature over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the U.S. The participants are restricted to using chainsaws exclusively for carving logs into animal and human forms. Last year's champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, is set to reappear and defend his title, aiming to keep the Claymore Trophy, the event's top prize.

Webb, a 27-year-old Wales rugby player, has been sidelined since sustaining a significant foot injury during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy in September. Despite this setback, he is nearing a comeback, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations tournament starting on 7 February, when Wales face Ireland in Dublin. Webb, who has earned 16 caps for Wales, has recently renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, opting to stay with his home region despite offers from other clubs. He expressed his commitment to both Wales and Ospreys, emphasizing his desire to be in peak form for national duty.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents in Washington state intercepted two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, who were attempting to smuggle ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. Hall, a Canadian citizen, dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and fled. Laviolette was apprehended. The backpacks contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, and one contained a driver's licence with Hall's name but his photo. Later, investigators arrested Kali Henifin, who was to meet the men at the border, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who was to drive the drugs for $11,000. The incident occurred in a known smuggling route, and all four individuals face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling calls, from 2,400 in 2011-12 to over 4,500 in the past year, indicating a rise in children's exposure to online abuse. The charity revealed that some children as young as seven have experienced severe torment, abuse, and fear of attending school due to online trolls. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized that cyberbullying can follow children home, causing persecution that they cannot escape. She urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying often escalates without intervention. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, highlights a young caller's experience of being told to commit suicide by an online group, causing distress and confusion for the child and their parents. The advice given by young people on dealing with bullying includes seeking support from trusted adults and standing up for oneself, while also acknowledging the challenges in doing so.

The passage discusses a series of events related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, primarily focusing on settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The US, under Secretary of State John Kerry, abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution on Friday, which condemned Israeli settlement expansion as illegal under international law and a significant obstacle to peace. This decision infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the White House of drafting the resolution and pushing for its passage. The US State Department denied these allegations.

More than 500,000 Jews reside in around 140 settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which Israel considers part of its territory, while the international community deems them illegal. The resolution, passed on Friday, stated that settlement construction has no legal validity and constitutes a major obstacle to achieving a two-state solution. Israel rejected the resolution, particularly the condemnation of East Jerusalem settlements.

In response, Netanyahu summoned the ambassadors of the US and 14 countries that voted in favor of the resolution, recalled Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and canceled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee initially planned to vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, but postponed it at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington before Kerry's speech.

Kerry is set to outline his vision for resolving the Israel-Palestinian conflict and address criticisms from the Israeli government. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as a step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France on January 15, aiming to establish a mechanism and timeline for ending the occupation.

In a BBC interview, Prince William paid tribute to the Queen on the eve of her 90th birthday, praising her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, marking the 500th anniversary of the postal service with a singing welcome from the Royal Mail choir. She then opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and met local schoolchildren. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their anticipation for the Queen's birthday. Prince William, in an interview, discussed his commitment to royal duties, acknowledging criticism but emphasizing his serious approach and the support of his family. He mentioned the Queen as his primary role model, highlighting her family-oriented approach. Ten stamps were released to commemorate the Queen's 90th birthday, featuring four generations of the Royal Family. On her actual birthday, the Queen will walk around Windsor and unveil a plaque for The Queen's Walkway, a 6.3km trail recognizing her record-breaking reign. In the evening, she will light a beacon, initiating a series of over 900 beacons worldwide. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch on Friday. The Queen, Britain's longest-reigning monarch, celebrates two birthdays annually, her actual birthday on 21 April and her official birthday in June. Republican group Republic criticized the extensive coverage, arguing it failed to present a balanced perspective.

In a League Two vs. Premier League EFL Cup match, West Ham United dominated Cheltenham Town with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew in the first half. Sakho scored from Sam Byram's pass, followed by Ayew's goal moments later. Cheltenham, who made seven changes due to recent top-flight losses, managed to create a few chances, including a low volley by Harry Pell and a header by Jordon Forster, but failed to convert. West Ham's defense, led by Robins captain Kyle Storer and goalkeeper Jonathan Flatt, kept Cheltenham at bay. The match ended with a 2-0 score in favor of West Ham, marking Cheltenham's exit from the competition.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer and father of four, tragically lost his life in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. The incident occurred when Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old from Leipzig, failed to notice a motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner, who was staying in a cottage with his family near Bala, pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family, understanding the accident was a momentary lapse, expressed no desire for Werner to serve jail time, acknowledging that nothing could bring their loved one back. Werner's defense attorney, Craig Hutchinson, reported that Werner expressed remorse but could not provide an explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British citizen from Southall, London, is a high-profile British jihadist who returned from Syria, where he fought with the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. Known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, Khawaja was a prominent figure in the group, posting videos and images of his activities on social media. He was involved in fundraising, creating propaganda, and sharing accounts of his experiences, appealing to young British Muslims. Despite his online presence, Khawaja's exact role in Syria remains unclear.

In June 2015, Khawaja decided to return to the UK, attempting to sneak back undetected. His cousin, Tahir Bhatti, facilitated his journey, but Khawaja faked his own death with an online obituary before attempting to enter the country. Upon arrival at Dover, the police intercepted them, leading to their prosecution at the Old Bailey. Khawaja has admitted to four offenses, including concealing his entry and faking his death.

The British security service, MI5, had been monitoring Khawaja. His cousin, Bhatti, who helped him return, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja, considered a dangerous individual, was initially held in Belmarsh prison's high-risk terrorism unit. He has admitted to four offenses, but an additional charge of soliciting to murder, the most serious allegation against a Syrian fighter, will be dismissed.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 matches for Wrexham last season, contributing to their eighth-place finish in the league. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, with the club preparing for their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Barnsley's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's speed, aggressive defensive approach, and his suitability for their playing style. Despite an offer from Wrexham, Jackson opted not to extend his contract with the club. For the most recent football transfer news, refer to the dedicated page.

Bottles, presumed to contain detergent from a container lost overboard during stormy weather near Land's End in May, have been washing up on several Cornish coasts, including Poldhu, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The National Trust, in collaboration with the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, is managing the cleanup due to potential harm to marine life. The bottles, though mostly full, are still a concern as they could contaminate the marine environment. The MV Blue Ocean is suspected as the source, but no definitive evidence links the bottles to this vessel. The Cornwall Wildlife Trust and Cornwall Council are closely monitoring the situation, advising the public to maintain a safe distance from the bottles and avoid attempting to recover them.

A collision took place on the A9 road, north of Berriedale in Caithness, at approximately 2:00 PM. This incident resulted in minor injuries to multiple individuals. As a consequence, the A9 was temporarily closed, and traffic was rerouted via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently investigating the cause of the accident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, contributing significantly to Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and their subsequent promotion to the Championship. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total for the club. Despite being overlooked earlier in the season, Dervite's performance improved towards the end, earning him a new contract. This move follows similar contracts signed by David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, all of whom also played a crucial role in Bolton's promotion to the Championship.

Liberal Democrat Lord Oates criticized Labour for allegedly being willing to "concede everything" in their opposition to the government, particularly regarding EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval. Baroness Smith, Labour's leader in the Lords, countered that the Lib Dems were instilling "false hope" in people. Both parties had previously collaborated to defeat government bills on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but this alliance dissolved when MPs rejected these amendments. Labour accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and building false hope, while the Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson, Baroness Ludford, blamed Labour for "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with Conservatives for a hard Brexit. Despite their past alliances on various issues like higher education and housing, the Lib Dems' Baroness Ludford expressed optimism about future cooperation, while a Labour source anticipated "residual tensions" and minimal efforts for a "progressive consensus" gathering.

In this election, defence is a low priority for most political parties in the UK, with it barely scraping into the top 10 of public concerns, trailing behind economy, NHS, and immigration. The UK's military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to a public sentiment of combat fatigue and political reluctance to discuss defence. Both Labour and Conservative manifestos offer limited detail on defence policies, with the Conservatives promising to replace Trident, increase defence equipment spending by 1% annually, and maintain the regular army's size. However, these commitments may hinder significant budget cuts due to the MoD's substantial non-protected budget of £34bn. The Royal Navy's fleet of 19 warships and the RAF's eight front-line squadrons are already reduced, and further cuts are likely. The UK's defence spending, currently at 1.7% of GDP, is projected to fall to 1.5% by the end of the decade, falling below the NATO threshold. The nuclear deterrent, Trident, is a contentious issue, with the Conservatives committed to renewing it, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats propose varying alternatives. The Royal Navy's new aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth and the Prince of Wales, are set to be operational by the end of the decade, but concerns exist about their crew capacity and the potential for a "hollow force" due to insufficient personnel.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, asserts they have not violated any rules regarding the transfer of Neymar, a 22-year-old striker from Santos, for a total fee of £48.6m (57m euros). This sum includes the initial purchase price, signing-on fee, wages over his five-year contract, agents' fees, and a recent tax payment. The club maintains that the actual cost could be higher due to additional contracts. Barcelona's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid allegations of misappropriating funds, which he denies. A Spanish judge has found sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona has made a voluntary tax declaration of 13.55m euros to address potential divergent interpretations of their tax obligations. Despite this, the club remains confident in their original tax payment. Neymar, since joining Barcelona, has scored 10 goals in 25 league matches, including 3 in the Champions League.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, was tragically killed in a motorway collision on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, when his van was struck by a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was going the wrong way on the motorway. Newman also perished in the incident. Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton and brother Simon, emphasized the importance of regular driving tests for older drivers, citing Luciw's youthfulness and promising future as a reason for advocating for such measures. They argue that older drivers' reactions slow down, and a mandatory test in a car with a driving instructor would provide a more accurate assessment of their driving abilities.

Andy Harrington, Luciw's colleague and a fellow delivery driver, described the traumatic event, stating that he barely managed to swerve to avoid the collision. Harrington, who sustained severe injuries, supports mandatory medical examinations for retired drivers. He expressed regret that Newman was on the road that morning, believing that Luciw would still be with his daughter.

Currently, UK drivers aged 70 and over are required to complete a self-assessment form every three years for license renewal, but this does not include a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that there is no evidence suggesting older drivers are more prone to causing serious accidents and that they must declare any medical conditions affecting their driving.

Caroline Abrahams, charity director of Age UK, stresses the significance of driving for older people in maintaining independence. She advocates for continued safe driving for as long as possible, emphasizing the need for supportive measures rather than restrictions based on age.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, which have been linked to severe side effects for numerous women. Two patients from the initial review group withdrew due to dissatisfaction with the report's findings. Independent expert Alison Britton, a professor from Glasgow Caledonian University, will now evaluate the review process and draw lessons for future independent reviews. The final report advises against routine procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, suggesting a range of treatments and informed patient choices. It also mandates mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a complete ban, the health secretary stated the government lacks the authority to enforce such a ban, as it falls to the UK regulatory body, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not unifying all panel members around the report's conclusions, acknowledging the difficulty of her task due to differing views. She took over the review in its final stages, having no prior communication with the previous chairwoman, Lesley Wilkie, who resigned for personal reasons. The review's final report faced criticism, with some women who suffered complications, including Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigning from the group, expressing dismay and disgust at the report's publication. It was later revealed that a consultant also left the expert group due to concerns about the final draft.

Over the past two decades, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have undergone mesh or tape implants, with some experiencing painful and debilitating complications. Currently, over 400 women are pursuing legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers due to mesh implant surgery complications.

Muir, a 23-year-old athlete, surpassed McColgan's 25-year-old 5,000m indoor record by 14 seconds, clocking 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan, the previous record holder, expressed excitement about Muir's achievement, despite initial concerns about the legitimacy of the record-breaking attempt. McColgan had questioned whether Muir's race, which was a mixed 3K and 5K event, met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts. British Athletics later confirmed that Muir's time would be officially ratified. McColgan, who previously held the British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final, praised Muir's talent, noting that Muir's 14.49 5K time was impressive but could potentially be improved to around 14.30. McColgan also drew a parallel between Muir's race and her own record-breaking performance 25 years ago, where she ran alone and lapped competitors.

In the show-jumping event of the Olympics, British rider William Fox-Pitt, 47, secured 12th place, despite a faultless performance in the final phase. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, had initially led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st following time penalties in the cross-country phase. His medal prospect was further diminished by a late infection contracted by his horse, Sam, necessitating a late replacement. France's Astier Nicolas and American Phillip Dutton secured silver and bronze, respectively. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. Fox-Pitt, who had been in an induced coma following a fall, made a comeback just 10 months later. The passage also mentions an opportunity to ride Henry, a mechanical horse, at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, secured a victory over Fabio Fognini, the 29th seed, in a grueling four-set match (6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5) lasting two hours and 39 minutes. Despite Fognini having five set points in the final set, Murray managed to win five consecutive games to clinch the match. The match concluded at 20:57 BST, with Murray advancing to the fourth round where he will face French player Benoit Paire. Murray expressed satisfaction with his performance, acknowledging it wasn't his best tennis but emphasizing his relief at securing a win. The match was intense, with Fognini showing both his talent and temperamental side, nearly forcing a fifth set due to darkness. Murray, who recently lost to Fognini on clay in Rome, managed to overcome the Italian's challenges, ultimately winning 7-5 in the fourth set.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, at 06:00 BST. Police discovered patrons still present at the bar, with till receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, violating licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both license holders, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The court heard that the premises had been operating beyond permitted hours. A defence solicitor admitted the premises were not being run properly. The judge, expressing concern over Ms O'Neill's "appalling record," imposed a three-month closure on the bar and fined Ms O'Neill £3,000 and Mr Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, concluded his speech with the statement, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does," emphasizing a shift in their election strategy, aiming to make it a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive issue. Following this, Nesbitt faced questions about his senior colleague Danny Kennedy's public distancing from his remarks. Nesbitt humorously acknowledged Kennedy's presence, stating it was reassuring. He firmly denied any regrets or mistakes, maintaining his stance that voters should choose Ulster Unionists and support candidates who align with their community's interests. Nesbitt expressed preference for an SDLP partnership over Sinn Féin, given the SDLP's more moderate stance. He reported positive reactions to his stance in unionist areas, despite the ongoing controversy. The party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership', outlines proposals for addressing healthcare waiting lists, increasing police numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is disadvantaged by Brexit. The manifesto also includes a section titled 'Cleaning Up Stormont', focusing on accountability and transparency. Nesbitt described the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption, hoping this message will resonate more than his earlier comments about transferring to the SDLP.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has announced that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland assembly for approval, aligning the region with England and Wales' plans for automatic pardons. This legislation, named 'Turing's Law', will grant posthumous pardons to men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, similar to the treatment in England and Wales. Additionally, it will enable living men with such convictions to apply for a pardon. The motion will cover both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men, ensuring equal treatment in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales. Sugden secured executive agreement to propose this legislative consent motion, aiming for swift implementation to rectify past injustices and expedite the process compared to an assembly bill. The motion is now set to be debated by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old athlete from Kinross, secured the second position in the 1500m race at the Scottish Championships, finishing in 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60, placing Muir second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her satisfaction with the new Scottish record, stating it holds significant personal value. She had previously competed in the 2016 World Championships, finishing fifth. Muir aims to qualify for the British team for the 2016 Rio Olympics at the upcoming British trials in Birmingham from June 24 to 26. Her season began with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and she is set to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm in the following week. Muir's training is integrated with her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year.
The passage describes a compilation of images from 26 Scottish beaches that have been recognized for their exceptional water quality, according to a specific ranking system.

The Metropolitan Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, asserts that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian FSB agent who defected to the UK in 2000. Horwell posits that the Russian state, with numerous reasons to harm Litvinenko, was likely the sponsor of the plot. Litvinenko died in 2006 after consuming tea laced with polonium-210, a radioactive substance, during a meeting with Kovtun and Lugovoi. Horwell emphasizes that the use of polonium indicates Russian state involvement, though he clarifies that this does not implicate President Vladimir Putin or provide evidence of his direct order. Litvinenko's criticisms of Putin and the FSB, as well as his defection, could have been perceived as treachery. Horwell also highlights that Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death, causing significant suffering. The suspects left a trail of polonium, and their lack of a credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them is a significant point. Despite the force's desire to prosecute the suspects for murder, extradition attempts have failed, and they remain in Russia. Kovtun, in particular, has been criticized for not attending the inquiry. The inquiry was adjourned until the following Friday.

Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Twenty20 team, succeeding Michael Clarke, who retired following a heavy Ashes defeat to England. Smith, who previously led the team in three Tests while Clarke was recovering from injuries, has been praised by national selector Rod Marsh for his talent and maturity. Fellow batsman David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite his past disciplinary issues, as Marsh believes Warner has matured and developed into a crucial senior figure. Both players will lead Australia in the upcoming limited-overs matches, starting with the final Ashes Test at the Oval on 20 August. Smith, with 32 Test appearances and a career average of 54.66, has scored 2,952 runs, while Warner, known for his batting prowess, will take on additional leadership responsibilities.

Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson's predecessor, John Farron, expressed his strong support for LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage during interviews this week. Despite being questioned multiple times about his stance on homosexual sex being a sin, Farron consistently maintained that he believes all are sinners. He emphasized his commitment to defending equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender individuals, citing the spousal veto as a barrier. Farron, who succeeded Norman Lamb in the leadership, stated that he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about individual liberties, though he didn't elaborate on these specific concerns. He reaffirmed his liberal stance and pledged to prioritize LGBT-plus rights as a key agenda item throughout his tenure as party leader.

In 2015, Sanofi, a French pharmaceutical company, ceased operations at its Fawdon manufacturing site in the UK, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, has taken over the plant for its own production. Accord Healthcare aims to rehire many of the former Sanofi employees, anticipating a positive impact on the local economy. Newcastle City Council's leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, expressed enthusiasm, highlighting the announcement as beneficial for Newcastle and the North East, reinforcing their reputation as a hub for science and healthcare. Accord Healthcare is known for its extensive range of over 130 pharmaceutical products, serving approximately 60 countries globally.

Richard Ellis, the interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving the local authority on Friday, concluding his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are also departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, perceives these departures as a sign of the council's struggle to retain senior staff, predicting more resignations in the near future. Council chief executive Angela Scott acknowledged their commitment and professionalism.

Martin, a British road racer, experienced a crash at this year's TT and his Honda Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical issues. Initially, he announced his retirement from road racing, but later clarified on Facebook that he's not abandoning racing altogether. He won't participate in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's uncompetitiveness, as confirmed by his team after testing at Cadwell. Martin did not enjoy the TT and felt the bike's performance was questionable even before the crash. He plans to focus on racing classics and non-standard events moving forward.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in the recent governorship and state assembly elections, winning 19 out of 28 governorship positions. This marks the most substantial defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month, suffered its first defeat in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and lost control of Adamawa, a state heavily affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. Despite this, the PDP managed to retain Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, predominantly in the south-east. The remaining results from Taraba and Imo states are still pending.

APC's historic gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the party's influence now limited to the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari, as militant groups could disrupt oil production. The elections, though marred by violence in parts of the country due to political rivalry and ethnic tensions, were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy.

The Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations, primarily in southern states where voting had to be extended. The APC retained power in Lagos state, the commercial capital, for the first time since multi-party democracy began in 1999. The PDP, after 16 years in power, is expected to undergo introspection and rebuilding under a new leadership, as voters sought change and the party faced defections of governors and MPs, along with corruption allegations and inadequate response to the north-east insurgency.

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its primary stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of potentially enabling unsustainable palm oil trading practices, which contribute to the annual haze affecting Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The haze is primarily caused by slash-and-burn methods employed by small-scale farmers and rogue palm oil traders in Indonesia. Olam claims to source 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and states it accounts for less than 1% of the global market. However, Mighty alleges that Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies," allowing the majority of its product to be sourced from unknown entities.

Olam's CEO, Sunny Verghese, maintains that the company has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and insists that all current suppliers meet these standards. He also asserts that the company's vetting and verification process will take several more years to complete. Temasek, as the majority stakeholder in Olam, is implicated in the allegations, with Mighty suggesting that Singapore's state fund could be indirectly linked to the haze issue due to its investment in Olam. Temasek denies these allegations, stating that they fully support no-burn policies and urge oil palm companies to do the same.

The passage also touches on the broader issues within the global palm oil industry, which is projected to be worth $88 billion by 2022. This industry is often criticized for unfair labor practices, deforestation, and the burning of plantations. Green groups and palm oil executives frequently clash over environmental standards, with activists advocating for stricter enforcement and governments arguing that these firms provide essential jobs and investment to rural areas. The report further highlights concerns in Gabon, where Olam is accused of clearing rainforests for monoc

On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started serving dishes named 'puppy platters' following a new regulation that permitted dogs to dine outdoors. The passage includes a humorous reference to the concept, likening the dish to a 'dog's dinner'. A video clip is also mentioned, providing visual evidence of this unusual dining experience.

Fernando Forestieri, a forward for the team, is currently uncertain due to a knee injury, having only played from the bench in the last two matches. Derby County's David Nugent, who has been sidelined with a groin issue, might be available for the upcoming game following his absence in the recent draw against Huddersfield. Additionally, midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who came on as a substitute to score a late equalizer in the match against Huddersfield, is anticipated to be recalled to the starting lineup.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator, the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA), has lifted the ban on YouTube following Google's launch of a Pakistan-specific version. This move was confirmed by the PTA, who instructed internet service providers to grant access to YouTube. Google has established a direct web process for the PTA to request the removal of offensive content, which Google will then address. However, YouTube maintains that government content removal requests are not automatically granted; they will only restrict access if a video violates their community guidelines or is deemed illegal in the respective country. The ban, initially imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 due to the controversial US-made film "Innocence of Muslims," resulted in widespread protests and over a dozen deaths in Pakistan. Google has since localized YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. Some activists, despite the ban's removal, are demanding transparency regarding the terms of this deal with Google.

Domenico Scala, the head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as are several presidential candidates, including Gianni Infantino. Scala previously recused himself from the 2015 elections due to a conflict of interest, as he shared nationality with the Swiss incumbent, Sepp Blatter. This move was also followed by Claudio Sulser. However, Musa Bility, the LFA boss, is threatening to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't withdraw by Thursday, citing the same conflict of interest. The upcoming election, scheduled for 26 February, will see five candidates, including Infantino, Prince Ali of Jordan, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, vying to replace Blatter. Bility, who was initially denied participation due to eligibility issues, has pledged his support to Prince Ali. The election, conducted by Fifa's 209 members, will be held in Zurich. The Liberian FA's threat to challenge Scala's continued involvement underscores the importance of maintaining fairness and integrity in the electoral process amidst Fifa's ongoing turmoil.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, perished at Harford Attachments, a company in Spar Road, while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were extracted from the scene on Tuesday. Forensic investigations are ongoing, with significant progress reported by Det Ch Insp Paul Durham. The cause of their death is suspected to be a flashover explosion, likely triggered by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, resulting in a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive is involved, with inspectors and electrical safety experts collecting evidence.

Tunisia and Morocco, both African nations, faced significant challenges in qualifying for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially threatened with disqualification after lodging complaints against CAF (Confederation of African Football) regarding a controversial penalty awarded during their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015. This incident led to a heated dispute, culminating in Tunisia's demand for an apology by CAF or risk disqualification from the 2017 tournament.

Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from participating in the 2017 qualifiers due to their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup citing Ebola concerns. However, this ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), reducing the fine imposed on Morocco's FA from $1m to $50,000.

Both nations' participation in the 2017 tournament was secured following meetings with CAF president Issa Hayatou, which facilitated a resolution to their respective issues. Tunisia, now preparing for their group stage matches, will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A. Morocco, in Group F, will compete against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

Should Tunisia advance to the 2017 finals in Gabon, they will break the record for the most consecutive Nations Cup appearances, reaching thirteen straight tournaments.

In a match at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City. The incident of concern occurred in the 95th minute, leading to the red cards for City's Sergio Aguero (second offense for violent conduct, resulting in a four-match ban) and Fernandinho (three-match ban for a clash with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas). City manager Pep Guardiola expressed regret for his team's actions. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge. Notably, Cesc Fabregas will not face additional disciplinary action.

The passage discusses a pilot program in the Cynon Valley and Castell-nedd, Wales, focusing on early cancer detection systems. The initiative aims to identify cancer cases without symptoms or signs, as currently, Welsh patients often don't receive a diagnosis until advanced stages. This pilot, which began this year, involves Denmark's health system for system evaluation. The Cwm Taf Health Board's health service in Wales has already shown positive results with early cancer detection rates. The concern is that many Welsh people may not exhibit typical symptoms, leading to delayed diagnoses. The plan is to have healthcare professionals trained in the system at Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg, Llantrisant, within the next few months. The pilot will involve 40 participants from the Cynon Valley, who will be asked to undergo tests and provide samples, with the goal of having results by the end of the month. Approximately 35% of the population in Cwm Taf has symptoms that lead to cancer diagnosis. Healthcare professionals will be trained in Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot as part of this additional pilot. The trial has been ongoing for 12 weeks among Welsh general practitioners in Aarhus. Denmark is now reviewing the diagnostic tools used in the region for cancer rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Cancer Cymru's Chief Executive, believes the pilot will not only confirm the effectiveness of the system but also encourage its wider implementation. Gareth Jordan, a healthcare professional from Aberdare, anticipates significant impact from the pilot. He expects to say, "I've seen this, I've had a lot of tests... and I haven't been given any further treatment or I wouldn't have had the opportunity to see a specialist." However, he acknowledges that the belief in early detection is crucial for preventing advanced stages. If the Cynon Valley pilot is successful, healthcare services in the area will be encouraged to adopt this method in the following months.

In the second Test match at Old Trafford, England secured a significant victory over Pakistan, winning by a substantial margin of 589 runs, their second-largest win in terms of runs. The hosts declared their innings at 589-8 and 173-1, showcasing dominant batting performances. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named the man of the match for his exceptional contributions. He scored 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second, while also taking four catches and claiming a wicket. Root's performance was praised by both captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss, who noted his improved control and focus.

Pakistan, batting for only 63 and 70 overs respectively, struggled on a pitch offering minimal assistance to bowlers. Their innings were marred by poor shot selection and a lack of confidence, with only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq managing to reach 50 runs in the series. Misbah acknowledged the team's disappointment, attributing their shortcomings to a lack of confidence and poor shot selection.

Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott commended England's comprehensive performance, predicting they will win the series, while also warning Pakistan to prepare for a challenging third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.
