Keating, who has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, is awaiting international clearance for his move. Nicholson praised Anderson for his leadership qualities, despite his limited game time, while describing Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone, have won only one of their last six matches.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who had previously won prestigious races like the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite showing no signs of post-race ataxia on the day of his death, Many Clouds had previously exhibited symptoms of overheating and wobbling on his feet, which led to his treatment for this condition. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence even in horses without underlying health issues. This incident has sparked discussions about understanding the causes and preventing such symptoms in sport horses.

In the Scottish Parliament, veteran politicians Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Tricia Marwick are stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, delivered a valedictory address, emphasizing Scotland's unity and the parliament's growing responsibility in governance. He acknowledged the Scotland Bill's positive impact but criticized it for not fully fulfilling pre-referendum pledges. Salmond also joked about the competition from the UK Chancellor's budget and the Cheltenham racecourse, expressing well-wishes for all election candidates.

McNeil, a Labour MSP, delivered an emotional farewell speech, urging the parliament to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. He expressed regret at having to learn from Westminster's practices.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, visibly moved by McNeil's speech, thanked Salmond for his distinguished service. Annabel Goldie, another departing MSP, concluded her speech with a light-hearted remark about her future interactions with the Finance Secretary, John Swinney.

The upcoming film, set to release in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, features Emma Watson as Belle, the protagonist from the classic tale. Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens portrays the Beast, while Luke Evans plays Gaston, the antagonist. Kevin Kline takes on the role of Maurice, Belle's father. The film's original Mrs. Potts, voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version, is reprised by an unnamed actress. Josh Gad, known for voicing Olaf in Frozen, will voice LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Bill Condon, director of Dreamgirls and the Twilight series, is helming the production, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to disclose its decisions regarding potential charges in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a private meeting with victims' relatives in Warrington, scheduled for 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans perished in this tragedy. Last year, new inquests confirmed the fans were unlawfully killed. The CPS has been reviewing evidence files of 23 suspects, with 15 linked to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 concerning the Independent Police Complaints Commission's probe into the police conduct following the incident. Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS, will inform the families of the decisions. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died, expressed hope that this is the final step towards justice, emphasizing the families' determination for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, with residents reporting seeing this occur four times in two weeks. A former inmate claims the prison is notorious for receiving mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, suggesting the use of drones for delivering contraband. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the staff's efforts to prevent contraband but emphasizes the need for additional measures. They've asked for a review to equip prisons with better tools to combat this issue. The Justice Secretary has also highlighted that laws now allow for up to two years' imprisonment for individuals found guilty of smuggling packages into prisons.

Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man from Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for causing serious injury by dangerous driving, specifically for hitting Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and does not remember if the traffic lights were red or green when he struck Mrs. Blackburn. He acknowledges striking her but denies causing her serious injuries. Mrs. Blackburn, a married mother of three with 20 years of service as a lollipop lady, is currently under residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, describing Mrs. Blackburn as much-loved and a beloved figure among the children. The incident occurred when Mrs. Blackburn was directing traffic as pupils left school, and Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light, hitting her while she was on duty. The prosecution stated that traffic in the other direction had stopped, but Wright did not. The trial is ongoing.

Scottish middle-distance runner, Jemma Reekie (referred to as Muir in the passage), will miss the 2022 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, 24, recently finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. Her exams commence in May, making it impossible for her to balance her academic commitments with the Commonwealth Games in April. Despite her absence, Muir expresses confidence in the team's performance and her own future prospects, including potential participation in at least two more Olympics. She also mentions the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target. Muir's personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds was set in a recent outdoor race in London, where she finished fifth in a tough competition.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, went missing on Christmas night in 2000 while walking home from a party. His disappearance led to a search in Chapelizod, Dublin, a three-acre woodland area near the R112 and the River Liffey. The search, initiated in early December, involves excavations and is projected to last several weeks. In April, CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance was enhanced, revealing Deely conversing with a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. This man is believed to have followed Deely shortly after the party. Despite the release of this footage and an appeal for the man's identification, he remains unidentified. Gardaí continue to seek his involvement in the investigation.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th, secured a 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 victory over Switzerland's Stan Wawrinka in a grueling Wimbledon match. Del Potro, who has been out for over two years due to wrist injuries, is now set to face either France's Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young in the next round. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, expressed immense joy and relief after the win, stating he's enjoying playing tennis again after a long period of struggle. Meanwhile, Australia's Nick Kyrgios, also in the same draw as Andy Murray, overcame a two-set deficit to beat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4 in a rain-affected match. Kyrgios will now play Feliciano Lopez in the third round, with the winner advancing to face Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Other notable wins included Tomas Berdych's 6-4, 6-1, 6-2 victory over Benjamin Becker and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga's 6-1, 6-4, 6-3 triumph over Juan Monaco.

Tunisia and Morocco, both African nations, faced significant challenges in qualifying for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially threatened with expulsion due to complaints lodged against CAF (Confederation of African Football) during the 2017 Nations Cup. However, after apologizing, Tunisia was allowed to participate. Morocco, on the other hand, was initially banned from the qualifiers due to their refusal to host the 2015 Nations Cup, citing Ebola concerns. This ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), reducing their fine from $1m to $50,000.

The 2015 Nations Cup was eventually hosted by Equatorial Guinea, who had to prepare in just 64 days. Tunisia, aiming for their first Nations Cup win since 2004, faced controversy in their quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea. A contentious penalty awarded led to a 2-1 loss in extra time, causing Tunisia to write a furious letter to CAF, leading to a demand for an apology or disqualification. Tunisia denied accusing CAF or the referee of corruption, instead criticizing the referee's selection.

A meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou in Senegal in mid-March facilitated a resolution, allowing Tunisia to participate. Morocco, meanwhile, was drawn into Group F alongside Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. Tunisia, in Group A, will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti. Should Tunisia advance to the 2017 finals in Gabon, they would secure their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance, a record.

McLaren, a renowned Formula One team with an impressive history of 182 wins, 12 world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, has experienced a significant decline since 2013. This slump began when the team lost its way in chassis design, despite retaining the powerful Honda engines. The current issue lies with the Honda power-unit, a stark contrast to their previous successful partnership with Honda, which led to their most triumphant era in 1988, where they won 15 out of 16 races.

The team's last constructors' title was in 1998, and they narrowly missed winning it in 2007 due to a points deduction for illegal information possession. Post-2012, victories have become scarce, and the wins have dried up as well. This current predicament mirrors McLaren's historical pattern of cyclical success and decline, following the team's establishment by Bruce McLaren in 1963.

Ron Dennis, who took control in 2009 after a disastrous 2013 season, aims to restore McLaren's dominance. He believes they will break Mercedes' dominance and win titles again, with two-time world champion Fernando Alonso returning in 2015. Despite the team's current struggles, Dennis and his team maintain optimism, citing progress in the car's performance and anticipating Honda's engine improvements for the upcoming season. Their future success, however, remains uncertain, hinging on the team's ability to regain form and deliver multiple championships.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, at 06:00 BST. Police discovered patrons still present at the bar, with till receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both license holders, were charged with violating licensing laws by allowing liquor consumption beyond permitted hours. O'Neill, with a history of non-compliance, was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000. The court acknowledged the poor management of the premises and expressed concern over the severity of O'Neill's record.

Stephen Curry surpassed his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry, who was four shy of his previous record of 272, hit eight 3-pointers before halftime and eight overall, aiding the Warriors' comeback from a 13-point deficit. Klay Thompson, his "Splash Brother," contributed 26 points. The Blazers' Lamarcus Aldridge and Damian Lillard had 27 and 20 points respectively. Elsewhere, Pau Gasol's 16 points and 15 rebounds, along with a 39-8 second-half run, helped the Chicago Bulls defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, dealing a significant blow to the Heat's playoff aspirations. Derrick Rose and Aaron Brooks each scored 14 points for the Bulls, who moved into the third spot in the Eastern Conference.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by Dutch free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen at Melwood training ground. Initially, they thought he was a competition winner who won the chance to meet the team and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, van Velzen quickly demonstrated his exceptional free-kick skills, leaving the Liverpool players impressed. Balotelli and Lambert particularly noticed his accuracy, with van Velzen scoring a goal into the top corner. Van Velzen, a YouTube sensation known for his free-kick videos, expressed his delight at the experience, especially meeting Balotelli and playing with his idols. He also revealed a personal touch by showing Balotelli his famous t-shirt from a 2011 Manchester City match against Manchester United.

The passage discusses the impact of the BRCA1 gene mutation on breast cancer risk and potential preventive measures. Women carrying this gene variant, like Hollywood star Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer post-diagnosis by undergoing an oophorectomy, or removal of the ovaries. A Canadian study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 mutations, finding that oophorectomy led to a 62% decrease in breast cancer deaths within 20 years. This protective effect was most pronounced in women who had the procedure within two years of diagnosis, with a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never underwent oophorectomy. The study also noted a 65% reduction in overall deaths. The protective effect was immediate and lasted for 15 years. The research emphasizes the importance of considering oophorectomy as part of initial treatment for BRCA1 mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer, particularly for those with estrogen-receptor negative cancer. The decision to undergo oophorectomy, as demonstrated by Jolie, does not diminish a woman's sense of femininity or self-identity.

On Easter Sunday, a married couple, Derek Loewe, 38, and Tina Loewe, 33, were tragically killed when an Amtrak train, the Carolinian (train no. 80), struck them on the tracks in Durham, North Carolina, around 10 am. The train, en route from Charlotte to New York City, was owned by Norfolk-Southern. Despite the incident, none of the 166 passengers on board were injured, except for a man who fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The train, delayed for approximately 2 hours and 45 minutes, resumed its journey. A man who had previously interacted with the couple, James Thompson, mentioned they might have been homeless, living in a scrap metal collection camp. The couple was last seen with a grocery cart and had asked Thompson to help them cross the railroad tracks due to their difficulties. Durham, located about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, is the next destination after New York City for the train's route. The journey from Charlotte to New York City typically takes around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years, providing crucial information that led to the downfall of high-profile drug figures like Carlos Lehder Rivera and Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, Toro was promised U.S. citizenship upon retirement but now faces deportation due to his declining health and the expiration of his temporary visa. He expressed fear for his life if returned to Colombia, stating he would be killed within four hours. The DEA, however, has refused to assist him with his citizenship application, leaving Toro in a state of limbo, unable to secure a green card, passport, or social security benefits. Former colleagues have offered him financial support to help him evade deportation, but Toro remains determined to receive the promised citizenship, describing his situation as a case of government bureaucracy at its worst.

The U.S. internet regulator, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for allegedly exploiting celebrities and companies by selling'sucks' domain names at high prices. These domains, such as youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, and others, were initially intended for trademark holders and celebrities to interact with critics, with Vox Populi charging around $2,499 annually. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains. The advisory body, comprising major companies and industry groups, has labeled this practice as a'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory'. ICANN has sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. If found so, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to modify its behavior.

A mother of a stillborn baby boy, discovered in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a Norfolk pond in 1988, was arrested 27 years later. The baby, named Peter, was exhumed in 2020 due to a periodic case review. DNA evidence led police to the mother, who admitted to concealing her pregnancy and delivering the stillborn baby herself. She placed the infant in the pond, known as Windmill Pit, on June 5, 1988, just before it was found by teenagers. The original investigation couldn't determine the cause of death, and a post-mortem in 2020 confirmed no foul play. The mother was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after her explanation. She remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied at St Peter's Church in Weasenham St Peter with a new headstone, named Peter, on June 5, 2020, the 26th anniversary of his discovery. The case was solved using advanced DNA technology, and a support group for stillborn parents funded the new headstone.

Michael Young, a 56-year-old former soldier and taxi driver from Bath, Somerset, was ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi in 2010. The incident occurred when Hicks, then 23, was returning home with his girlfriend from a night out. Young, mistakenly believing Hicks intended to "do a runner" and not pay the fare, decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. Despite Hicks' objections, Young continued driving for nearly a mile, leading to Hicks' escape. Hicks jumped from the moving vehicle at over 20mph, sustaining devastating brain injuries, epilepsy, and requiring round-the-clock care from his mother.

In a high court ruling, Mr. Justice Edis found that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact compensation amount, estimated to be around 50% of what the family had requested (hundreds of thousands of pounds), is yet to be decided. The judge acknowledged the significant risk Young's actions posed to Hicks' life and limb, and reduced the damages by 50%. Hicks' family, represented by lawyer James Davies, emphasized the life-altering impact of the injuries, including post-traumatic epilepsy, headaches, fatigue, social and behavioral problems, and a loss of sense of taste and smell, leaving him unable to work. Both parties have been granted permission to appeal, and a subsequent hearing will determine the precise compensation amount.

On Wednesday night, Kansas experienced tornado sirens due to multiple storms, with reports of tornadoes in Goddard (6 miles northwest of Wichita) and southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. A tornado was also suspected in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, causing wind damage, flooding, and hail up to baseball size. The National Weather Service warned of more storms in the midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive win since losing to Vitor Belfort, is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey this Saturday. Rockhold, a mixed martial artist with a diverse skill set, intends to dominate Machida, who is known for his evasive, dancing style. Rockhold plans to cut off Machida's space, slowly progress, and exploit perceived weaknesses in his opponent's game. He acknowledges Machida's respected martial arts prowess and the potential for a competitive fight, but remains confident in his ability to outmaneuver and defeat Machida, potentially securing a title shot. Machida, too, is prepared and believes his strategy can lead to victory, emphasizing his readiness to capitalize on any mistakes made by Rockhold during the fight. Both fighters have recently secured victories, with Rockhold's last win being against Michael Bisping and Machida's against CB Dollaway.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar, was captured on video touching down at Aero Acres Residential Airpark without deploying its landing gear. The plane, traveling at speed, appeared to make a normal descent until it touched down with a bump, causing its belly to scrape along the runway. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, who has flown for nearly 50 years, initially failed to deploy the landing gear, leading to a gear-up landing, also known as a belly landing. The impact caused the propellers to ricochet off the ground, damaging them. Despite the damage, the pilot managed to re-engage the engines and take off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is often caused by human error, such as forgetting to deploy the landing gear, or mechanical faults.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season, acknowledging that the Ivorian has underperformed. Despite this, Pellegrini has pledged to support Toure until the end of the current season, emphasizing the player's importance to the team. City, facing a challenging campaign with just 18 points from the last 39 available, is considering selling Toure in the summer to revamp their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his contract worth £220,000-a-week, is also under scrutiny due to the team's defensive struggles. City's goalkeeper, Joe Hart, has taken responsibility for the team's underperformance, stating that players have let the manager down. Meanwhile, West Ham's manager Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell against joining Manchester City, citing the poor experiences of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who also moved to City but saw limited playing time. Allardyce believes Cresswell could be an attractive addition due to his potential to help clubs meet homegrown player quotas.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," was set to be extradited to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for his role in the Cosa Nostra. However, his case was dismissed in October 2014 due to Italian law, which states that a sentence becomes void after more than double the imposed term. Rancadore, who has lived in the UK for over 20 years, was initially arrested in 2013 on an Italian arrest warrant. Despite his conviction for being a "man of honour" and taking bribes, the Italian court agreed to extinguish his conviction, rendering his extradition unnecessary. The European Arrest Warrant against him is now to be withdrawn, allowing Rancadore to remain in the UK with his family. The extradition process, involving multiple court hearings and legal challenges, was criticized for its length and cost by legal experts. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) acknowledged a mistake in failing to serve appeal papers on time, which may have contributed to the case's prolonged duration.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other favorites are Special Tiara, an Irish raider, and Sacre, trained by Nicky Henderson and ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This will be McCoy's final ride in a grade one race, with his book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey to be finalized on Friday morning. Interestingly, McCoy's decision to retire was announced after winning the Newbury race with Mr. Mole in February. Other competitors in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia, a girl murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time, 40 years after her daughter's death. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Her body was discovered 33 days post-disappearance, and Ritter's ex-husband advised her against seeing the body and photos. Last year, Ritter, driven by a desire to confront the reality, asked Metro Police lead investigator Mickey Miller to show her the photos. Miller initially tried to dissuade her, but she persisted. Ritter described the gruesome state of Marcia's body, including swelling, a blackened mouth, hair pulled out, and blood on her scalp. She expressed a strong emotional reaction, saying she would have wanted to kill Barrett if she had a gun. The case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett, then 68, was arrested in 2006 for the murder of Vanderbilt University student Sarah Vannatta Des Prez. DNA evidence linked him to Marcia's clothing, leading to his conviction for second-degree murder in 2009, with a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, is determined to win the Masters Tournament to complete a career Grand Slam, a feat achieved by only six players in history. He considers this his most significant day in his career, following his collapse in the 2011 Masters. McIlroy, who has yet to secure a top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, aims to become the sixth player to win all four major titles, following Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. He emphasizes the importance of winning every major to demonstrate versatility across diverse golf courses and conditions. McIlroy's 2011 collapse, where he led by four shots and ended with an 80, was the most crucial moment in his career, teaching him valuable lessons about resilience and adaptation. Despite personal distractions like postponing his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a legal dispute with his former management company, McIlroy aims to use the Masters as a sanctuary from external pressures, focusing on his game and the course. He is optimistic about his chances at Augusta, viewing it as a golf course he can excel on and potentially win multiple times.

This week witnessed several trending stories, including natural phenomena and celebrity-related news. In the New York area, four rainbows appeared after a significant rainfall, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, the practice of hiring exotic dancers for mourning wakes is gaining traction, now under scrutiny due to the country's anti-vice campaign. Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ) became agitated during a UK interview about his personal life. A new trend, lip plumping through sucking on a jar, inspired by Kylie Jenner, gained popularity with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. Filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker relive her past. A school's refusal of a prom-posal referencing bombs sparked controversy, with the prom-poser alleging racism. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', and Johnny Depp's transformation in the 'Black Mass' trailer drew significant attention. A unique pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', while a military dad photobombed his son's photos. These stories, along with others, dominated social media discussions this week.

In the past year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), a condition caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy, according to the official health and social care information centre. This figure represents a significant portion of the estimated 7,500 UK babies annually who may suffer learning, behavioural, and physical issues due to maternal alcohol consumption, as per World Health Organization research. These problems can include deformed limbs, learning disabilities, behavioural challenges, and various organ malfunctions like liver, kidney, and heart issues, cerebral palsy, vision loss, and epilepsy.

Elizabeth Mitchell, from the National Organization for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, emphasized that children with FAS do not recover and that the condition is severe, often underdiagnosed. A notable case is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who was diagnosed with FAS at age five. She requires assistance with daily tasks and lacks a sense of danger, indicating she will never live independently. Niamh's adoptive parents, Julia and Simon, established the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust to support others affected by this condition.

Experts advise pregnant women to avoid alcohol entirely, with the current government recommendation being up to two units no more than twice a week. However, Mitchell advocates for a stricter "no alcohol during pregnancy" policy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, known as 'Boomerang Boy' or 'Homing Pigeon Boy', was a notorious ex-juvenile offender from Coundon, near Bishop Auckland, who was jailed for six years after attempting to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15. At 8 PM, the 31-year-old masked man, wielding an axe, demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. However, his plan was thwarted when store owner Sab Dhillon tackled him, causing him to fall and knock over shelves and produce. Sab Dhillon's wife, Sam, then intervened, hitting McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him and revealing his face to the cameras. The police arrived shortly after and arrested McKerry, who had previously been arrested 80 times by the age of 15, with convictions for aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary. His nickname originated in the 1990s due to his habit of returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Fibow, 23, a submarine engineer from Stockbridge, Hampshire; Craig Stoner, 24, from Stonehouse, Gloucestershire; Simon Radford, 31, of Gosport, Hampshire; and Darren Smalley, 35, also from Gosport—were charged with gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The incident occurred on April 10, following a hockey game. The victim, aged in her early 20s and a Halifax resident, was at the base with a friend who was invited by local Canadian servicemen. The accused are alleged to have engaged in sexual intercourse with the victim.

The men appeared in a Dartmouth court, near Halifax, where they were granted unusual bail conditions. They must stay in Nova Scotia, live at the nearby Stadacona naval base in Halifax, and surrender their passports. They will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay, as agreed with the British government. The bail amount for each was over £2,000.

The four sailors, who were playing for the Royal Navy ice hockey team in a tournament at the Shearwater naval base, were ordered not to contact the victim or six witnesses, and must not leave Nova Scotia or apply for new passports. They were also forbidden from resigning from the navy without court permission.

The case is being treated as serious by the British High Commission, with Commander Michael O'Sullivan describing the alleged offences as 'disturbing.' The investigation is ongoing, and forensic test results could lead to additional charges. The sailors were relieved to be out of custody and were driven to their new base. They were instructed to return to court on May 27 and were forbidden from discussing their plea. The charges include sexual assault causing bodily

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, is caring for her four-year-old son, RJ, who suffers from an extremely rare skin condition called Netherton's Syndrome. This disease causes RJ's skin to appear red, scaly, and often covered in dry, flaky scales. Valerie regularly applies creams to prevent his skin from drying out and to alleviate the associated pain. Despite her efforts, RJ faces numerous challenges due to the condition, including denial of entry to play centers and cruel comments from strangers.

Their ordeal escalated when a member of the public reported Valerie to the police, accusing her of child abuse due to RJ's visibly affected skin. Armed police were dispatched, and Valerie was surrounded while shopping. She expressed disbelief at the public's ignorance, stating that such misunderstandings highlight the lack of awareness about rare diseases.

Netherton's Syndrome is a congenital skin disorder, a severe form of ichthyosis, characterized by red, scaly skin, hair, infection, and allergy issues. It often manifests at birth, causing rapid heat, water, and protein loss, leading to inflammation and increased infection risk. Symptoms can worsen with age, with skin remaining red and scaly, and becoming itchy, sensitive, or raw. There's no cure, but most children's symptoms improve over time.

Valerie discovered RJ's condition through a Facebook group for Netherton's Syndrome, where she found support and advice from parents worldwide. Despite the challenges, RJ is a happy, bubbly boy who loves playing with his siblings. Valerie hopes that as RJ grows, his condition will be more understood, emphasizing that beneath his red skin, she sees a beautiful child.

The controversial advertisements for protein world, featuring a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield, have been removed from the London Underground after a three-week period. The posters sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, with over 50,000 signatures on a change.org petition calling for their removal. Critics argue that the advertisements promote an unhealthy body image and objectify women, implying that only those who look like the model are 'beach body ready'. The adverts were also defaced by bloggers and social media users. Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the removal due to the end of the advertising period, stating they would consider the reaction to future similar campaigns. The company, however, maintains that the image is unaltered and the campaign aims to inspire healthier lifestyles. Despite the controversy, sales of protein powder in the UK are increasing, with projections reaching £358m by 2017. Some, like TV presenter Susanna Reid, have criticized the ad as anxiety-inducing, while others, such as Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick, have defended the brand, advocating for personal responsibility in fitness and body image.

Rail firms, particularly First Great Western (FGW), are facing criticism for planning significant fare hikes, up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, contradicting pledges from main party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened, requesting FGW to "urgently review" its decision to nearly double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. The proposed changes have sparked outrage among constituents, with Cameron's spokesman confirming the prime minister's letter to FGW. Train companies have three annual windows to increase unregulated fares, which account for about half of their revenue, including off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets. FGW justifies the increase by aligning the north Cotswolds route with other services, while offering a cheaper alternative in advanced single tickets. Other notable hikes include Virgin's fare increases on the London Midland route, with some anytime first-class single tickets rising by 22%, and a 24.5% hike on the Stafford to Liverpool route. Virgin defends these increases, stating that the majority affect their own cheaper 'Virgin trains-only fares', which are at least 20% less expensive than rival tickets. Despite these hikes, Virgin claims their overall fare increase this year on the West Coast is just 1.65%, below the industry average.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were attacked in their home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, by vandals who threw stones at their property. When John confronted the attackers through his front door, he was struck in the left eye with a brick, resulting in a serious injury and permanent blindness. The incident occurred on April 18, three weeks after their wedding, while they were writing thank you notes for wedding gifts. The couple, who had met just 14 months prior, expressed shock and fear, stating they never had any issues before and don't understand why they were targeted. Police are investigating the attack, suggesting it might have been a case of youths "messing around," with no apparent motive. The couple, now living in Southport, are too scared to return to their old home. Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam urged anyone with information to contact the police.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension until the end of the 2016 season. He missed the 2014 campaign due to severe leg injuries sustained in a road accident where his father, Keith, tragically died in April. Poynton underwent an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. His return has been marked by exceptional character and hard work, as acknowledged by Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch. The club is optimistic about his performance this summer, noting his good form since his return to training.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, battled an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children annually in the UK. Diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck, Harley used a ninja turtle mask to boost his courage during radiotherapy. His story gained international attention, leading to a Christmas box of Ninja Turtle presents from Nickelodeon. After a year of intensive treatment, including chemotherapy, a kidney tumour removal, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester, Harley was declared cancer-free. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, expressed immense joy and hope for his return to full-time school. Harley's bravery earned him recognition from Cancer Research UK, and he now represents their kids and teens campaign, aiming to raise funds for child cancer research. Neuroblastoma, a cancer of specialized nerve cells, commonly affects children under five and can spread to various body parts. Symptoms vary based on the tumour's location, often including fatigue, loss of appetite, and bone pain. Diagnosis involves various tests, and treatment depends on the child's age, tumour size, position, and spread.

Tim Sherwood, former Aston Villa manager, advises 19-year-old Jack Grealish to prioritize his club career with Aston Villa over his international ambitions. Grealish, who has been impressing in Villa's matches, including their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, is currently in a tug-of-war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood, who previously guided Nabil Bentaleb through a similar situation, emphasizes that Grealish should make the decision based on his heart, not external pressures. He believes Grealish's confidence and skill, evident in his performances, will only improve with more first-team opportunities. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports this view, stating that his son should focus on Villa's success first before considering international calls. The decision is expected to be made at the end of the season, with Grealish potentially playing for both nations in an upcoming friendly match.

The passage discusses the significant disparity in landing fees for private jets at various international airports, which are primarily utilized by the wealthy and famous. These fees can range from thousands to tens of thousands of dollars per landing, depending on the airport. Some of the most expensive include Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, charging £4,559 (approximately $6,850), Narita International Airport in Tokyo, charging £3,728 (around $5,600), and Kansai International Airport in Osaka, charging £3,594 (about $5,400). Other notable expensive airports are in Europe, such as Dublin Airport at £2,729, and in North America, including La Guardia Airport in New York at £2,630. The most popular private jet routes, according to private charter companies, are from Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome. The list of the most expensive airports for landing fees is compiled by a website called 'the richest', based on the 767-400 aircraft, which can accommodate up to 50 passengers. Interestingly, three of the most expensive airports are in Japan, with Haneda Airport being the priciest.

Katie Gallegos, owner of Dogpatch Resort in Clackamas County, Oregon, shared a video of her dog, Cooper, and his friend Daisy, enjoying ice cream from a McDonald's drive-thru. Cooper, known for his quick eating, consumes the entire cone in one bite, while Daisy takes more delicate licks. The video, which has garnered over seven million views, has sparked mixed reactions, with some finding it endearing and others criticizing the feeding of fast food to dogs. Gallegos, an animal lover, defends her actions, emphasizing Cooper's good health and the occasional ice cream treat she gave to her past dog, Sammy, who lived to 19 years old. Another video shows Cooper and Daisy visiting a Starbucks for a 'pup-uccino', where Cooper also devours the entire beverage, which is essentially a dollop of whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed permanently to a three-year contract. He previously served as an assistant coach under Allan Johnston, joining the club last summer. Locke took over as the team's manager in February following Johnston's departure. Since then, he has maintained a winning record, losing only once in seven games at Rugby Park. Locke is set to address the media on Friday morning to officially announce his new role.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, from Eustis, has alleged that Seminole County Elementary school threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he uses to manage his condition. These oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied to Logan's head and neck by his mother, as she believes they help him stay calm and focused. The school claims the scent of these oils distracts other students. Despite the threat of punishment, Kemp maintains that the oils have a positive impact on her son and intends to continue using them. The school district initially threatened to suspend Logan, citing a "problem" for staff and students, but later reversed the decision, stating it was a "health issue." The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which Doterra describes as having "beautifully and powerfully fragrant" properties.

A beach-side apartment complex, known as the Sandpiper, in Westhampton, Hamptons, was completely destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday afternoon at 3 PM. The blaze, which started undetermined, spread rapidly through 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The intensity of the fire was so extreme that it melted the paint off nearby structures, visible up to three miles away. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, including the use of cranes to approach the flames, they were unable to enter the summer homes due to the intense heat. The building manager, Rob Taber, lost everything in the fire. Residents reported seeing flames from a distance of three miles. The fire chief stated that the offshore wind helped in maintaining visibility for the firefighting efforts. The complex, open from May to November, is now reduced to rubble, leaving its owners and managers devastated. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with suspicions pointing towards a car parked near the complex.

The 88-year-old Queen, despite nearing her 89th birthday, was recently seen enjoying a ride in Windsor Great Park on her black fell pony, CarltonLima Emma. She is known for her long-standing love of horses, having her first pony, Peggy, at the age of four. The Queen, who has never worn a riding helmet, prefers a silk scarf for protection. She breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court and has a stud specializing in highland ponies at Balmoral. Her fondness for these ponies, originating from the Neolithic period, is evident as she continues to ride and breed them, with some of her grandchildren, like Prince Edward's children, Lady Louise and James, Viscount Severn, also riding them. The Queen's interest in fell ponies is rooted in their historical significance as pack animals, used by the Romans, Vikings, and Normans, and later as trotting horses in the 1950s. Today, they remain popular for riding, with the Queen being a familiar figure at her Windsor stables.

An argument between two Brisbane neighbours, Leon Yeaman, 55, and Phillip Pama, 28, escalated over noise levels, resulting in Yeaman's death by a single punch from Pama. The incident occurred around 9 PM on Thursday night in front of their North Brisbane homes. Yeaman was reportedly making loud noise in his yard on Muller Road. Pama, a married father of three working a 3 AM shift at a nearby warehouse, confronted Yeaman, who was known for excessive drinking, loud music, and verbal outbursts. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama acted impulsively, grabbing Yeaman by the hand and striking blindly while being pushed at the same time. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 PM. Pama, who has no prior violent history, was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, including a curfew and reporting to the local police station twice a week. He appeared visibly distressed outside the courts. The case is scheduled to reconvene on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, was arrested in Shatura, near Moscow, after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-student, Damian Vanya. Simonova, who had been showering Vanya with gifts and money for a year before their relationship ended, sought a £1,400 payment for the 'hit'. She detailed her desire for Vanya to endure severe pain, including broken limbs, kidney damage, and a slow, painful death. The plan was to be carried out by an undercover police officer posing as a hitman. After receiving part of the payment, Simonova was arrested in her car. She now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship to be with a classmate, expressed relief at the arrest.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, publicly expressed his daily prayer routine to God, emphasizing that he never discusses football with his faith. He and his family are aware of poverty and have been involved with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. Mourinho, 52, maintains a clear separation between his professional and personal life, with his faith being a personal aspect. He acknowledged his competitive and emotional nature on the football field, admitting to making mistakes, but stressed that a person's life extends beyond their professional role. Mourinho, a father of two, has been spotted at events like the Victoria's Secret fashion show and the Hunger Games premiere with his family. Despite his intense on-field persona, he is described as a good family man and friend, and actively supports individuals he doesn't know. He was previously fined by football authorities for criticizing a perceived campaign against Chelsea.

On April 1, 2021, for the first time in eight years, TV icon Bob Barker, who previously hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years until 2007, returned to the show. At 91, he appeared fit and took charge of the initial game, "Lucky Seven." After completing this segment, he handed over to current host Drew Carey, who concluded the show. Despite his extended absence, Barker demonstrated no signs of rust in his hosting skills.

An off-duty U.S. Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. around midnight on Friday, 3200 block of D Street SE, for allegedly attempting to burglarize a residence. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police Department apprehended him, and the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin, assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which handles diplomatic activities, was due to be arraigned in court on Friday afternoon. This incident follows another high-ranking supervisor's placement on leave due to misconduct allegations, both under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General. The Secret Service is currently facing scrutiny over these events, including a previous incident where two officials were accused of driving into a secure White House area after a night of drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, bravely approached a hungry male lion at the city's safari park. Despite being armed only with a camera, he managed to get within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to capture images. However, the sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, prompting it to charge. Saeed quickly retreated to his car, narrowly escaping the lion's aggressive attack. He later expressed regret for the close encounter, emphasizing the lion's aggressive behavior.

New York City police have released an image of a distinctive heart tattoo with the name 'Monique' found on an unidentified woman, who died in Brooklyn last month. The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Despite her lack of identification, she had the tattoo on her right leg, which was a faded heart with the name 'Monique' inscribed within a ribbon and topped with a rose. The cause of her death is still pending a medical examiner's report. Anyone with information about the woman is encouraged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a unique, solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck they purchased after returning from the UK in 2009. Unable to afford a full-sized property, they embarked on a year-and-a-half project, constructing the home piece by piece. The couple, who value a connection with nature, designed the home with wood and steel, featuring a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and a loft for their cat. The home is nearly self-sufficient, drawing most of its electricity from solar panels and water from a nearby spring. The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000. Hannah and Alex are content with their eco-friendly, cozy abode, and they even contemplate building another one in the future.

Research conducted by Courtney Blackwell from Northwestern University indicates that kindergarten students who share iPads in class significantly outperform their peers in early literacy tests. The study, involving 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district over an academic year, found that shared iPad users scored approximately 30 points higher than those using the device individually and non-ipad users. The key factor, according to Blackwell, is the collaborative learning that occurs around the shared technology, rather than just the collaboration itself. This suggests that schools should reconsider the use of iPads, particularly in earlier grades, to maximize their educational benefits.

A piglet, born without hind legs in Qionglai city, Sichuan province, China, has gained internet fame due to a video showcasing its remarkable ability to walk on just its front trotters. Despite numerous near-tipping-over moments, the piglet, nicknamed 'Super Pig', consistently maintains balance while foraging for food. This two-legged piglet coexists harmoniously with its siblings, all born with full sets of legs. Farmer Ms. Duan, its mother, discovered the unique condition when she noticed the piglet feeding with an unusual gait. The piglet's extraordinary balance has drawn thousands of admirers, with villagers frequently visiting to witness its antics. This isn't the first case of a two-legged animal captivating China; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also gained popularity for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, Todd Phillips, a tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car struck him while exiting the pit box on lap 25. Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel, spun out, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips sustained a cut that required stitches and was treated at the infield care center before being released. Dracone, from Italy, did not complete the race and finished 23rd. The race was challenging due to prior rainfall affecting traction for many cars.

The passage describes a brutal murder in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where 32-year-old Milton Vieira Severiano, a husband of 29-year-old dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, killed her by smashing her head against concrete paving 11 times and shooting her in the face 5 times. Severiano confessed to the crime, admitting his jealousy over men admiring her. The incident occurred four days after their marriage, following an argument where he called her a "slut." Cicera, known as Amanda Bueno, was a member of the dance troupe "Jaula das Gostozuedas." After the attack, Severiano stole a neighbor's car during his escape but was apprehended after crashing it. Police discovered four handguns, a shotgun, and a bullet-proof vest in his vehicle. Severiano now faces a life sentence for the murder.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has publicly discussed her personal struggle with mental illness, specifically anxiety, which led her to contemplate ending her life. In a candid interview with Women's Weekly Australia, Wilson revealed that her anxiety, coupled with mounting stress, thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation due to her lack of a husband and children, pushed her to a point where she couldn't see the purpose in continuing. She felt extremely alone and couldn't envision a way out. Despite recent personal growth, Wilson still identifies as an anxious person, noting that she felt like she missed out on a guidebook to life while observing others manage their anxiety. She emphasizes the growing link between depression and anxiety, stating that anxiety is increasingly becoming the "new depression" in Australia, with one in three women expected to experience anxiety in their lifetime. Wilson encourages seeking help for mental health issues, urging those in need to contact Beyondblue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old woman from Portland, Oregon, who was seven months pregnant at the time, was initially charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 for striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after discovering her using heroin in their shared bathroom. The ex-girlfriend, who had a history of heroin use and had previously gotten high with Curtin's boyfriend, refused to leave the apartment when asked. Curtin, justified by Oregon law which permits physical force against an intruder refusing to vacate, used a crowbar to attack her. Her defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, revealed that the ex-girlfriend had been persistently making Curtin's life difficult, including harassment, theft, and attempts to reintroduce her boyfriend to drug addiction. The boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, had struggled with heroin in the past. The couple had a five-year-old child, but the ex-girlfriend had not been involved in the child's life. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory six-year prison sentence. However, prosecutors dropped the charges, citing Curtin's justified outrage, and she gave birth in January. The couple has since reconciled, and Curtin is now living with her parents.

Gemma, a Pit Bull residing in California, was filmed being fed treats at home. Her owner attempted to trick her by adding broccoli to the mix. However, Gemma's reaction was one of disgust as she bit into the vegetable and promptly spat it out on the floor. This incident serves as a cautionary tale for the two children she lives with, urging them not to emulate her aversion to vegetables. Despite this, other videos show Gemma enjoying her time sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has publicly apologized for an embarrassing technical error on its official website, where a link intended for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page led visitors to a pornographic site. This issue occurred due to the awards' cancellation in 2011, and the organizers' decision to allow the registration of the porn site on HSBC's Hong Kong branch (hsbc.hk). The bank's URL, which typically directs to third-party sites, inadvertently transferred visitors to the adult content site. HSBC promptly removed the offending link and issued an apology, denying any association with the external site. The bank's internet banking services, including account management, fund transfers, and loan applications, remain unaffected and secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, demonstrated remarkable bravery during a house fire in Clinton on Sunday morning. After smelling smoke, he called 911 at around 7 am, informing the dispatcher that he and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to intense heat. Despite the situation, Marcus remained calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing clear instructions to firefighters. He informed them that his older brother, mother, and step-father were also inside the house. When Aaliyah panicked and said they were going to die, Marcus reassured her, telling her to stay low and reminding her to breathe. He guided the firefighters to the room by describing the location of a black door in the back hallway. Prince George's County firefighters, led by Lt. Kenny Ward, entered the room through a broken window and rescued Marcus and Aaliyah. Ward handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer, while also giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other family members, including Marcus' brother, mother, and step-father, managed to escape on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, specifically Noctiluca scintillans, have been causing a spectacular, neon glow along Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. This phenomenon, described as a 'beautiful supernatural scene' by photographer Andy Hutchinson, is a result of millions of these single-celled plankton emitting light. Similar displays were observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. The algae, which blooms in spring and autumn, is a natural occurrence, according to Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales. These carnivorous cells, known for preying on diatoms, emit light as a defense mechanism.

New genetic tests, known as endopredict, are being introduced for breast cancer patients to identify specific markers in tumors that indicate the cancer's aggressiveness and recurrence risk. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed in a lab, providing results within days. For some women, these tests can accurately determine a low recurrence risk of less than 5%, comparable to or even better than chemotherapy's odds. This means that for these women, chemotherapy may not be necessary, as it often comes with severe side effects. The tests, currently available privately for around £2,500, are being advocated for by healthcare professionals due to potential cost savings from avoiding chemotherapy. Becca Cornford, a breast cancer survivor, exemplifies this, as her endopredict test revealed a 5% recurrence risk within ten years, allowing her to opt out of chemotherapy. Regular monitoring is emphasized as an alternative to chemotherapy for those with low recurrence risks.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with at least one woman removed from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed 'HMS Lusty', during the last nine years. This trend is not limited to a single ship; 18 other vessels, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also experienced emergency evacuations. The data indicates that these women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave, as per a strict 'no touching' rule at sea. The issue has been a concern since 1990, with women making up around 9% of the Royal Navy's personnel. Notably, in 2014, 9% of British soldiers were female. In 2013, 16 women were evacuated from Afghanistan due to pregnancy, and 18 in 2011. A total of 99 servicewomen were flown back to the UK between 2006 and 2013. The military has a policy prohibiting pregnant women from serving in war zones, and they are returned to the UK at the earliest opportunity.

A drone discovered on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House in Tokyo, carrying traces of radioactive cesium, has sparked alarm about potential terrorism involving drones in Japan. The drone, 50 centimeters wide with four propellers, was found by a staff member on Wednesday morning. It was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material, believed to be cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The cesium was also found in areas around the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant following its 2011 meltdown. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who was not present at his office, is currently in Indonesia attending a conference. The discovery has heightened concerns about future terrorist threats at events like the Olympics and G7 summit, prompting the government to review and strengthen drone operation regulations and counter-terrorism measures.

A security guard from Zhejiang province, China, named Lu Xincai, is caring for his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother, who previously worked on a farm. Due to her condition, Lu Xincai fears she might get lost if left alone. To ensure her safety, he transports her on the back of his motorbike to work daily, a four-kilometer journey that takes an hour. He ties a sash around both their waists to prevent falls. Lu Xincai's wife works in a different city and his son is still in school, leaving him as the primary caregiver. Despite the physical strain, he feels a duty to care for his mother, who once carried him on her back when they were children. At work, he regularly checks on her, ensuring she's in her designated room. He describes their relationship as one of mutual care and reciprocity, with his mother's dedication to raising her children now reflected in his own care for her.

A significant study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, reveals a 17.2% rise in heavy alcohol consumption among Americans between 2005 and 2012. This trend is particularly pronounced in women, with their heavy drinking rates increasing by 36% in Santa Clara County, California, compared to 23% in men. Nationwide, women's heavy drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate among men. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men in a single occasion, also saw substantial growth, with women's rates increasing more than seven times the rate among men. The study, the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, found that despite the rise in heavy drinking, overall alcohol consumption hasn't significantly changed. The county with the lowest binge drinking rate in 2012 was Madison County, Idaho (6%), while Menominee, Wisconsin, had the highest (36%). The study also highlights that cultural shifts, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies have contributed to this trend, with increased affluence, tech industry presence, and cheaper alcohol due to lower taxes and increased advertising.

Unofficial health experts, including the World Health Organization (WHO), caution that excessive caesarean sections (C-sections) are endangering the health of women and their newborns. They emphasize that C-sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can result in infections and even fatalities. In England, over a quarter of births are now C-sections, a figure that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO recommends this rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%, citing the associated dangers and costs. They highlight that while C-sections can save lives, they are often performed without medical necessity, leading to potential short- and long-term health issues, disabilities, or even death. The procedure is also costly, with an average NHS cost of £2,369 for a planned C-section compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO's stance contradicts current NHS guidelines, which suggest offering C-sections even without medical justification. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has revised recommendations, allowing C-sections for women anxious about childbirth (tokophobia) and those with specific medical conditions. However, the WHO argues that doctors are performing C-sections too frequently and underestimating the risks. Previous studies indicate that up to one in ten C-sections may lead to infections.

Michelle Filkins, a 44-year-old woman from West Wareham, has been arrested for breaking into a $800,000 home on Martha's Vineyard, residing there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was apprehended on April 17 by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, who found her in his living room. Filkins claimed ownership of the house but fled when Conklin called the police. Upon arrival, officers found a broken window covered by a blanket. Filkins was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home. She faces charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The stolen items, valued at around $2,000, include furniture, a grill, lamps, and a painting. Police are urging anyone who received these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department for potential restitution.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was recovered after she handed it in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police, realizing the phone was unlocked, posted humorous selfies and photos of the phone in various locations within the police station on Bella's Facebook page. These posts included puns like "it's a great 'cell' phone" and a joke about the phone being "fully charged" when she collected it. The police also used the time to post a picture of the phone in a holding cell and reassured Bella that it was safe. When Bella arrived to collect her phone, she found the original post had gained significant attention from her friends, who had shared it. The police continued their light-hearted approach even after Bella's arrival, with one officer texting her friends to keep her informed. Bella, amused by the situation, didn't need to provide her name upon reclaiming the phone as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police's unusual method of tracking down the phone's owner was widely praised by Bella and her friends, who labeled them as "legends." Bella has since added a password to her phone, expressing gratitude to the police for their sense of humor and successful recovery.

In the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, eastern South Africa, a five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed during a fight between two adult males. The calf's mother, observing the conflict from a safe distance, attempted to protect her offspring by driving away other hippos. Despite her efforts, one of the adult males seized the calf, flinging it into the air. The calf was then dragged along the water's surface, suffering fatal injuries. The mother hippo unsuccessfully tried to retrieve her calf, and the sub-adult hippo, either intending to kill or playing, bit down harder, ultimately causing the calf's death hours later.

A three-bedroom maisonette in Knightsbridge, one of London's most expensive areas, is listed for £575,000, significantly lower than the average three-bedroom property in the area. However, the property has a critical catch: it has only three years left on its lease, which would cost around £191,000 annually or £15,000 monthly, comparable to renting a similar flat in the area. If the lease is extended, the property could potentially be worth up to £6 million. The 1,990 sq/ft apartment, described as 'bright and well proportioned,' includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. It's currently unmodernized and needs substantial renovation, such as in one of its bedrooms. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million, with a 28-year lease. The property is part of the exclusive Egerton Place, built in 1893 by John Grover and Son, featuring high-quality architecture. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease to 90 years could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Potential buyers include locals, developers, and end-users, with agents estimating a modernized version could sell for between £2,750 and £3,000 per sq/ft. Despite its low price, a property consultant warns that extending the lease will incur a significant premium.

Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage affecting 8,000 U.S. and Canadian stores, causing registers to malfunction and preventing credit card transactions. This issue began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. In response, baristas offered free drinks to customers, leading to a wave of social media sharing and excitement. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, was resolved late Friday night, with stores expected to reopen on Saturday. Despite the temporary free-drink policy, some locations, particularly in Florida, Tennessee, and Arizona, closed their doors to avoid distributing free products. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record-breaking quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with shares rising 4.4% following the announcement.

Terrorist training activities are reportedly taking place in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These individuals, who are Muslims, engage in seemingly ordinary community activities but have a hidden agenda of radicalization. The use of these rural locations for training dates back to 1998 when Abu Hamza sent a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, Powys. The rugged terrain of these areas is utilized by the British military for soldier training, including elite forces like the SAS. Notable incidents include the 2005 photographs of two 7/7 bombers, Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer, white water rafting in Bala, North Wales, and the 2010 arrest of three Cardiff-based men planning Mumbai-style attacks. Additionally, Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder. The institute, set up by Iraqi clerics, has been linked to terrorist activities. Detective Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence in identifying and preventing such radicalization efforts.

A rare and previously thought-extinct species of whale, the Omura's whale, was discovered washed up on Exmouth Beach in Western Australia following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. Identification was initially challenging due to its unique skeletal features, such as 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, but was confirmed through DNA profiling. The whale, a juvenile female measuring 5.68 meters, was found in waters typically inhabited by the species in Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Environment Minister Albert Jacob highlighted the significance of this discovery, emphasizing that it will aid in improving field identification guides and understanding the whale's regional distribution. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be excavated in a few years for further scientific study and potential public display in museums.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's potential presidency, with some arguing that her hormones might lead to irrational decisions, particularly in starting unnecessary wars. This argument is contrasted with the historical evidence of male leaders' hormonal influences negatively impacting their decision-making, citing examples like Arnold Schwarzenegger, Mark Sanford, and John Edwards. The text also highlights the bias against women in leadership roles, emphasizing that even in 2015, a female candidate faces significant challenges due to this bias. It references studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men, and the economic benefits of gender equality in the workplace, such as increased corporate profits, improved child well-being, and stronger marriages. The passage concludes by urging a shift in perspective, encouraging the belief that women can achieve any role despite societal prejudices, and advocating for a more inclusive and equitable political landscape.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, renowned for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and various portrayals of Winston Churchill, is auctioning off over 200 antiques, valued at £100,000, due to downsizing his home. The collection includes a diverse range of items such as furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. Notable pieces are a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the longbow. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, on Saturday, features 238 lots. Hardy, an expert on medieval history and a former student of J.R.R. Tolkien, has built this collection through his interest in classic literature and military history. Despite his retirement from stage acting due to a fall, Hardy continues to engage in television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida resident, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother's body was discovered. Police believe there was foul play. Shemansky, already on parole for battery on law enforcement and with a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His mother was reportedly helping him navigate a divorce. Neighbors speculate that his mother may have prevented him from attending the visit, and the stress of the divorce proceedings and recent legal troubles could have pushed him over the edge. Shemansky fled the scene on foot without supplies or medication. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed the method of her death. His estranged wife is preparing for his potential arrival at her home and urges the public to report any information about Shemansky's whereabouts to 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been selected by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the typical bidding process due to a perceived strategic advantage in hosting the event for the first time in the U.S. This decision was influenced by a compelling presentation to the IAAF, which convinced them that Eugene possesses the necessary capabilities to organize a successful world championships. Eugene previously missed out on hosting the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar, home to the Aspire Dome. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of this choice, involving public authorities, private sector, national Olympic committees, NBC, and a supportive public. This move mirrors the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, which were also awarded without a bidding process. Notably, Mo Farah, a British runner, won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in London's West End. Granger befriended Hassan, a frequent casino player, using her attractiveness, receiving gifts, cash, and luxury dates from him. On the night of the murder, she left her flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. They tied up, kicked, and brutally killed Hassan, stealing his winnings and other valuables. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. The court described the attack as "pitiless and wicked," emphasizing the brutality and lack of compassion involved. Granger's defense argued she was manipulated by Jackson due to her love for him, but the judge noted her deceitful nature and loss of compassion from the start. The trial revealed Hassan's vulnerability due to his enjoyment of female company and his habit of keeping large sums of cash at home.

Cesc Fabregas, the Chelsea midfielder, has been experiencing a decline in form during the second half of the season, particularly after Christmas. This trend was evident in Spain's 2-0 defeat against Holland on Tuesday, where he received a low rating from a Spanish newspaper. Despite his initial promise, with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, Fabregas has managed only one assist in the subsequent five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. This dip in performance has raised concerns about his durability and consistency, especially considering his role as a key player in Chelsea's title chase. Manager Jose Mourinho will be keen to see Fabregas regain his form, as he has been instrumental in creating goals for the team, including an assist for Diego Costa in Chelsea's 3-2 win over Hull City. However, with nine games left, Chelsea still faces six teams that Fabregas has opened up for goals this season. A late-season resurgence could significantly impact Chelsea's Premier League title race.

West Ham United are in advanced talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican prodigy Deshane Beckford, who has been impressing during a trial period at their academy. Beckford, hailing from Montego Bay United, has spent two weeks training with West Ham and has received offers from Belgian clubs. He is considered one of the most promising talents from the Caribbean.
